===== WikiGameToolkit =====

One of the many pastimes of people on RockMonkey is the creation of WikiGames (such as RestlessWorld and WikiBridgePuzzle). To assist in the creation of WikiGames, [[DanHuntley I]] have created this page.

----
==== 1. General Design Tips ====

~- When designing a wiki-based adventure (or other) game, use the WantedPages list to determine which links you have not yet 'finished'. When testing a [[WikiGames WikiGame]] on behalf of the creator, do not 'create' missing pages (unless invited to), because this makes it very difficult for them to find and 'fix' missing pages.

~- Sketch out a design on paper before you start: outline what the game will be about and how it will be fulfilled.

~- Avoid making 'GameOver' situations where it is not possible that the player will have been given any warning beforehand. (RestlessBoy - this is no fun)
----
==== 2. Advanced [[WikiGames WikiGame]] Tools ====
=== 2.1. Inventory Management ===
~- Thanks to a plug-in I've written, it is now possible to 'give' your players 'items' which they will carry around until relieved of them.

~- To give your player an item, simply include a line like %%{{InvPickup item="Bowl Of Porridge"}}%% in your code. If the player does not already have the item, they will be told that they now do, and it will be added to their inventory (shown at the side of the window). To see this in action, and to examine a code example, visit WikiGameToolkitDemoPickup and WikiGameToolkitDemoPickup2.

~- To force your player to lose an item, simple add a line like %%{{InvDrop item="Bowl Of Porridge"}}%% in your code. If the player has the item, they will be informed that they no longer have it and it will be removed from their inventory. To see this working, visit WikiGameToolkitDemoDrop and WikiGameToolkitDemoDrop2.

~- To show a link only if a player has a certain item or at least one of a number of items, use: %%{{InvHasOne item="Bowl Of Porridge" link="WikiGameToolkitDemoEatPorridge" text="Eat the porridge"}}%% For more complex examples of usage, see WikiGameToolkitDemoHasOne.

~- To show a link only if a player **does not** has a certain item or at least one of a number of items, use: %%{{InvHasNone item="Bowl Of Porridge" link="WikiGameToolkitDemoGoHungry" text="Wish that you had some porridge?"}}%% For more complex examples of usage, see WikiGameToolkitDemoHasNone.

~- To show a link only if a player has **all** of the items in a set, use: %%{{InvHasAll item="Bowl Of Porridge/Wooden Spoon" link="WikiGameToolkitDemoEatPorridgeWithSpoon" text="Eat the porridge with the spoon"}}%% This works a lot like ""InvHasOne"", but the link is only shown if the player has **every** item in the slash-separated list.

~- **Do not** make a [[WikiGames WikiGame]] in which it is possible to entirely 'get stuck' if you do not have a certain item. Death and other 'GameOver' conditions are fine, but please include a 'Try Again' link back to the front page of your game.

~- Remember to add lines to the front page of your game to force your players to 'drop' all of the items that feature in your game, //before// they start, otherwise they'll be able to cheat very easily. Cheating is still possible - as in any [[WikiGames WikiGame]] - but if you follow these guidelines then it can't be done 'accidently'.
----
=== 2.2. Tokens ===
Tokens are a kind of semi-persistent variable: a named token that can be assigned a value that can be retrieved later. They can basically be used for all the same things as objects (above) can be used for, but also a lot more, too.

~- To set a token, use the following syntax: %%{{SetToken token="myTokenName" value="fred"}}%% This will set the value of the token "myTokenName" to "fred". You can store pretty much any kind of data in a token, but the thing they're most useful for storing is numbers.

~- To display the value of a token, use: %%{{GetToken token="myTokenName"}}%% If the previous code had been executed, this would output the word "fred" to the screen.

~- If you've put a numerical value into a token, you can do simple mathematical operations upon it. This code will increment the value of the "myValue" token by 5: %%{{SetToken token="myValue" value="+5"}}%% And the following code will decrement it by 3: %%{{SetToken token="myValue" value="-5"}}%% See the code that manages the scoring mechanism in WikiScissorsStonePaper an example of this.

~- You can also use SetToken to generate random numbers: %%{{SetToken token="diceRoll" value="random(1,6)"}}%% The code shown above will generate a random number between 1 and 6 (inclusive) and put it into the token called "myValue". If you then entered the following code: %%{{SetToken token="diceRoll" value="+random(1,6)"}}%% You would increment the value by another random number between one and six - this accurately simulates the rolling of two six-sided dice.

~- **Coming soon:** The ability to duplicate token values and set token values in relation to one another.
----
=== 2.3. Conditional Logic ===
We've already seen that we can use """InvHasOne""", """InvHasNone""" and """InvHasAll""" to test whether a player is carrying a particular object or objects (see code in TromaNightAdventure for examples of this). What's more useful is the ability to integrate more complex logic into your WikiGames:

~- You can test the value of a token, the state of the inventory, or the currently logged-in user, using the Test directive. The result of the Test is executed immediately. The syntax is: %%{{Test if="[expression]" then="[result]"}}%% It is also possible to add an 'else' clause, which will be executed if the expression evaluates to false, using: %%{{Test if="[expression]" then="[result]" else="[other result]"}}%%

~- Expressions are written in the form "1 = 2". For example, the following code: %%{{Test if="1 = 2" then="One is equal to two!" else="One is not equal to two!"}}%% Will always print out "One is not equal to two!", because the expression "1 = 2" will always evaluate to false. However, the code: %%{{Test if="1 = 1" then="Yay; they're the same!" else="They're not the same!"}}%% Will always return "Yay; they're the same!", because "1 = 1" will always evaluate to true.

~- Valid operators for use in expressions are = (equal to), < (less than), and > (greater than).

~- You can substitute a token value in place of a literal in an expression using the getToken function, as shown below: %%{{Test if="getToken(playerScore) > 50" then="You got over fifty points!" else="You got fifty or less points!"}}%% This snippet of code will print out "You got over fifty points!" is the value in the "playerScore" variable is greater than 50, and "You got fifty or less points!" otherwise. Be advised that it is not sensible to increment a player's score "on the fly" during a game, as they may (accidently or deliberately) press the "refresh" button on their browser to increment their score again! Better to set a series of tokens for each "achievement" they have managed on their journey, and add up a score at the end (see TromaNight230 - the TromaNightAdventure score page, for an example of this).

~- You can even compare tokens to one another, e.g. %%{{Test if="getToken(money) > getToken(sense)" then="You have more money than sense!"}}%%

~- You can use a Test code block to execute other syntax blocks (for example, """SetToken""" or [[WikiFormattingRules images]]), but this is a nightmare to get your head around. Look at example code in, for example, WikiScissorsStonePaper for an example, and look at the following code block (notice use of ~(, ~, and }~ inside the "then" block): %%{{Test if="getToken(money) = 0" then="You have no money, so the old man gives 5 coins: ~{SetToken token=~money~ value=~+5~}~"}}%%

~- You can also use all the usual boolean operators (and, or, and not [expressed an a preceeding exclamation mark]). For example: %%{{Test if="(getToken(money) = 0) and !(getToken(visitedOldMan) = 1)" then="YYou have no money, and the 'visitedOldMan' token is not equal to 1."}}%%

~- Other constructs that can be used in an expression include isUser("""UserName"""), which evaluates to 'true' if the player is logged in as the specified user name, hasItem("""ItemName"""), which evaluates to true if the player has the specified item in thier inventory, and countItems("""ItemOne"""/"""ItemTwo"""/"""ItemThree"""), which evaluates to the number of items from the slash-seperated list that the player has. In the example (countItems("""ItemOne"""/"""ItemTwo"""/"""ItemThree""")), this would evaluate to 3 only if the player had """ItemOne""", """ItemTwo""", and """ItemThree"""; to 2 if he had only 2 of them, and so on.

~- **Do not try to embed a Test block within a Test block**. If you need this kind of multi-level functionality, you will need to set a temporary token and test for it later, in a seperate test block.

~- **Tip 1**: Remember that Test blocks, like """SetToken""" and the like, will print out a blank line on the resulting page if you put them on a line by themselves (which could leave giveaway 'gaps' on your page, indicating that code is being run). To alleviate this, try to put code blocks (series' of Tests, etc) on the same line.

~- **Tip 2**: The whitespace in Test expressions is necessary. Sorry.

~- **Tip 3**: If you get stuck, find DanHuntley on the [[ChatRoom RockMonkey ChatRoom]] and drop him a note and he'll try to sort it for you. =o)

====Pass the Page====

Remember in School when you used to get a piece of paper and fold it over and then you'd each write a piece of a story, without seeing what the person before you had written? 
It always ended up being a story about Uncle Jim and Aunt Jemima having sex with a turkey in space while being shot at by a cowboy...

This is just like that, but using futuristic technology!

I couldn't think of a name for it so I've called it 'Pass the Page'

How we do it:

**[[PassThePageOne Click here]]** to find the first page of the first 'Pass the Page' (the idea is we can do some more. You'll find a list of the parts of the story. Go to the first one that is as-yet-unwritten and add your bit of the story (only do one page, leave some for everyone else). Then read/write-protect it. When all the pages are complete everyone can unprotect the pages (or Dan can make a program that'll do it for us) and we can read the completed story! 

Another fantstic use of the [[internet]].

The [[Splurg]] is the MortalEnemy and ancient protaganist of the FleebleWidget. Very little is known about its habitat, breeding habits or anatomy, save that it is the one creature in the whole of existence to be truly two-dimensional.

This allows it to sneak up on its prey by turning sideways so that it is invisible, then suddenly turning to face its hapless victim, which is then scared to death by the [[Splurg]]'s terrifying spiky visage and implausibly jagged mouth.

The [[Splurg]], having no digestive organs, is then unable to eat its prey.

If there is a point to all this, it is yet to be discovered.

====Kittens====
(sometimes spelled as [[Kittins]])

Younger version of [[Cats]]. [[Kittens]] elicit high-pitched squealing and irrational behaviour from otherwise sensible [[Humans]]. Especially if given balls of [[Wool]].

====Pigs====

Highly intelligent pink barnyard-based animals. They are the source of all [[Bacon]] in the world, as only they know where it is hidden. [[Vegetarians]] consider this exploitation and argue that we should not eat bacon, but should allow [[Pigs]] to keep it all for themselves.

The favoured noise of a [[Pigs Pig]] is 'Oink!'.

A [[Pigs Pig]] was once narrowly beaten as the Conservative candidate for MP for [[Daventry]], it was felt its position on immigration was not strong enough.

===Birds===

[[Birds]] are the only animals in the whole world that can fly. Apart from [[Bats]], [[Geese]], [[Ducks]], [[Flies]], [[Butterflies]], WingedAnts, [[Bluebottles]], [[Dragonflies]], certain varieties of [[Pigs]] (but not [[GuineaPigs]]) and [[Humans]]. 

They live in nests made of sticks and leaves and lay [[Eggs]] in them. This is because [[Birds]] have not invented houses. Sometimes [[Humans]] build bird houses for them to live in, though this practice went into decline after GordonBrown declared that bird houses were liable for CouncilTax.

The collective term for [[Birds]] is a [[Flap]].

----
[[AnimalKingdom List of all members of the AnimalKingdom]]

===Ducks===

Quacking water-based fowl. Subsist only on donations of stale [[bread]] from [[Morons TheGeneralPublic]]. 

The most popular [[Ducks Duck]] of all time is DonaldDuck, who was the captain of the [[Titanic]] before going on to star in his on [[Cartoon]] series.

The least popular [[Ducks Duck]] of all time was the unnamed [[Mallard]] whose mournful quacking in a partially submerged tube caused 2004's [[Asian]] [[Tsunami]]. (see ChaosTheory)

[[Ducks]] are sometimes mistaken for [[Birds]]

The collective term for [[Ducks]] is a [[Twaddle]].

====Moo Cows====

[[Milk]] producing animal. Famous for going Moo. They live in fields where they produce [[Methane]] and think about [[Sex]].

Some [[MooCow MooCows]] participate in the DaventryMooCowOrchestra.

The collective term for [[MooCow MooCows]] is a [[Tapestry]].

see also BaaLamb

[[AnimalKingdom List of all members of the AnimalKingdom]]

====Sheep====

The plural of [[Sheep]] is [[Sheep]] this makes it impossible to know how many [[Sheep]] there are in any given location. Therefore counting [[Sheep]] helps people fall asleep as it a never-ending and highly tedious task.

[[Sheep]] were the inventors of [[Wool]] and wear it constantly.

Their favoured noise is 'Baa!'.

Outside of [[Wales]] people often make jokes that [[Welsh]] people have [[Sex]] with [[Sheep]], this is not true though Shepherds around the world may sometimes use a [[Sheep]] to keep their [[Penis Penis}]] warm on a windy day.

Staunch anti-individualists, [[Sheep]] are forbidden from saying any word other than 'Baa'. Young [[Sheep]] are therefore known as [[BaaLamb BaaLambs]].

The collective term for [[Sheep]] is as a [[Hive]].

----
[[AnimalKingdom List of all members of the AnimalKingdom]]

====Cats====

[[Cats]] are widely adored by YoungGirls and OldLadies, who if single must own at least one to qualify for a state pension. 

Their popularity is only equalled by the utter contempt shown by [[Cats]] to their proponents.

[[Cats]] do not play games as [[Dogs]] do, being far too aloof. However they enjoy the following activities:

~- Slaying smaller animals and leaving them on the kitchen floor - [[Cats]] do this knowing it upsets and disgusts people, aware that they will be forgiven as [[Humans]] will attribute it to an attempt to provide sustenance for their beloved family. Inside they are howling with laughter.

~- Exposing their [[Anus Anuses]] - [[Cats]]' favourite way to show contempt for those who love them is to walk away with their tails high in the air exposing a small pink patch.

Much of the appeal of [[Cats]] comes from the fact that they begin life as [[Kittens]].

[[Cats]] are the arch rivals or [[Dogs]]. [[DogsVsCats The Conflict]]

The collective term for [[Cats]] is a [[Resentment]].

==== [[Grue]] ====

As transcribed from the EncyclopaediaFrobozzica, a compilation of all things from the GreatUndergroundEmpire, also known as "[[Zork]]".

----
The [[Grue grue]] is a sinister, lurking presence in the dark places of the earth. Its favorite diet is either adventurers or enchanters, but its insatiable appetite is tempered by its horrible fear of light. No [[Grue grues]] have ever been seen by the light of day, and only a few have been observed in their underground lairs. Of those who have seen [[Grue grues]], few ever survived their fearsome jaws to tell the tale.

[[Grue Grues]] have sharp claws and fangs, and an uncontrollable tendency to slaver and gurgle. They are certainly the most evil-tempered of all creatures; to say they are touchy is a dangerous understatement. "Sour as a [[Grue grue]]" is a common expression, even among themselves.
----

{{image class="right" alt="Slint" title="Can't you just tell they rock like motherfuckers?" url="http://www.ondarock.it/photo/Slint2.jpg"}}(nicked from billions.com and wiki-ised)

[[Slint]] established its earliest roots when, in 1981, at the ages of
eleven and twelve, guitarist BrianMcMahan and drummer BrittWalford
began playing together in Louisville, Kentucky KY. In [[1984]], BrittWalford and
guitarist DavidPajo started collaborating musically at the ages of
fourteen and sixteen. 1985 saw the origination of Slint itself, the
band then comprising BrittWalford, DavidPajo, and bassist EthanBuckler. BrianMcMahan joined the following year.

In 1987, [[Slint]] recorded their debut album, "Tweez", with SteveAlbini
behind the board in [[Chicago]] and released it on the short-lived and
enigmatic JenniferHartmanRecordsandTapes label. At this time,
EthanBuckler departed and was replaced on bass by ToddBrashear. 1989
saw the recording of their untitled EP, engineered by SteveAlbini,
mixed by BrianPaulson, and released by TouchandGoRecords.

In 1990, [[Slint]] recorded the landmark "Spiderland" album in Chicago
with BrianPaulson both engineering and mixing. This release, in
particular, became an IndependentMusic touchstone, loved and admired
by hundreds of thousands of fans and emulated by a generation of
musicians.

The following year, the year in which "Spiderland" was issued by [[TouchAndGoRecords TouchAndGo]], [[Slint]] broke up. For almost fourteen years, the members have not performed together as [[Slint]]. Now, for a very short time, they do so again.

==== AberystwythArtsCentre ====

{{Image url="http://www.aberystwythartscentre.co.uk/html/images/img-aboutus.jpg" class="right" alt="Arts Centre; rear entrance and studio theatre"}} AberystwythArtsCentre is a large building high on PenglaisCampus - near the StudentsUnion building and HughOwenLibrary - which combines theatre, cinema, gallery, [[ArtsCentreBar bar]], cafe, and shops. It was built in 1970 by the UniversityOfWalesAberystwyth, at a cost of just over 1 million. A 4.3 million redevelopment project in 2000 brought a pottery studio, print room, darkroom, video suite, recording studio and music rooms, the ArtsCentreCinema (120 seats), dance studios, studio theatre, new gallery, bars, craftshop, bookshop, and a complete development of the theatre foyer.

These days the Arts Centre is a busy and vibrant venue with over 500,000 visitors a year and a programme of over 800 events each year - including the annual StudentSkillsCompetition. It employs  120 full-time staff and has a turnover of over 2.5 million.

A fairly dull position in the Government. Probably just as scared of the GeneralElection as every other monkey in the House of Commons.

NegativeCampaigning is a shoddy [[GeneralElection election]] tactic, the opposite of PositiveCampaigning, which involves saying things like "If you vote for us, we will do this, this, and this, and that will be good for you because of this other thing that will happen." 

NegativeCampaigning, however, involves saying things like "If you vote for //them// the world will end. And all your children will be [[QuadrupleFlyingBumrape QuadrupleFlyingBumraped]] by immigrants who will put you out of work. And the leader of the other party will become PrimeMinister and pimp your mum.

For some reason, NegativeCampaigning is becoming ever-more popular in the UK, probably because the Yanks like it too, and it requires far less effor than thinking of ways you could make the voters happy, and the country a better place.

----
See also: GeneralElection.
See also: PositiveCampaigning

PositiveCampaigning is where you tell the electorate that voting for you will be good for them, assuming you don't break all your promises. 

Unfortunately, all Governments break the promises they made when they actually //needed// the public, so it is hard to run an [[GeneralElection election]] campaign and use PositiveCampaigning at the same time, because you'll break all your promises as soon as you come to power, and you have to invent lots of policies that sound good and - ideally - are somehow supported by facts or statistics.

Because of this, everyone involved in UK politics finds NegativeCampaigning much less effort, and will continue to do so until they lose the election, and blame the other side's NegativeCampaigning, and say what a dirty trick it was. [[Wanker Wankers]]
----
See also: GeneralElection.

====Chapter One: Stance====
----

A man can find himself in a variety of situations each day, from working to relaxing with friends in a pub. A man is always in a state of heightened awareness, ready to defend his woman and property from all challengers. However, a man should also be able to relax around his friends, and shouldn't worry too much about his appearence in social situations. Your attitude should have more of an impact than how you look, so there is no need to follow this chapter to the letter.

In order to discourage any attempts to lower your status from competing males, you need to perfect a stance which will make you seem both threatening, yet relaxed and confident.

It is often said that your body-language is that which says the most about you. A man's body language shouldn't //say// anything about you, it should //shout// about you.

===Standing===

If standing, you should have your arms folded, and you should be leaning against something. If possible, cross one leg over the other, to give an appearence of relaxation. 

If possible, you should never fully face someone who is talking (unless the conversation involves physical threats, interesting conversation, or a lady), but always keep your gaze pointed slightly to the side of your focal point. This will benefits you in two ways; first, it makes the person addressing you think you are uninterested, and hence they will try harder to engage you. This lowers their status in the group, as they're having to compete to gain you attention; this behaviour reinforces your dominance over everyone around you. Secondly, it lets you increase your field of vision, which may give you that valuable fraction of a second required in the event of an attack, or if a lady walks into the room.

===Part 1: Cursing.===

When you're cursing someone of something, don't hold back. If you string various SwearWords together, and slowly build their level of profanity - you always end up in one of two possible places. [[Fuck]], or [[Cunt]].

Hence, you need to cut out anything before those. A real man knows what he wants to say, and is confident in his opinions.

Hence:

~-"[[Piss]] off" becomes "[[Fuck]] off".
~-"I don't like you" becomes "You're a [[Cunt cunt]]".
~-"I don't like you, go away" becomes "[[Fuck]] off you fucking [[Cunt cunt]]".

And so on.

==== Chapter Five: Food ====

Being a man doesn't involve much cooking. 

If you've read this far, you should be able to either coerce a woman or threaten a man into doing it for you. However, you do need to be the master of two thing; meat and barbecues.

=== Meat ===

Good meat is the cornerstone of a manly diet. You need to eat meat at least twice a day, preferable for breakfast and for your evening meal. This way, you'll never lose the taste for blood that a true man craves.

I won't go into detail about how to prepare and cook meat, because it's not my forte. Your woman should deal with these things. However, it is important to remember that a true man will only appreciate good quality meat. While a McDonalds hamburger may take the hunger away for a while, only a real fillet steak, rubbed with pepper and barbecue sauce will truly satisfy a real man.

=== Barbecue ===

Whether you're cooking sausages in a hole in the ground on an open fire, or cooking steak for 50 on a multi-plate outdoor barbecue which needs it's own forest to power, you need to follow some simple rules.

* Always stay in control. The alpha-male in a given situation is always the one holding the tongs, fighting it out toe-to-toe with the raging heat of the flames. If you're not that man, you're a nobody at this meal. 

* Don't let anyone take your position in front of the barbecue from you, no matter what is offered. You may be tempted to leave the flames for a second, to open a beer, to chat to your mates, or even to cool off (poof). Don't do this. 

* Be wary of challengers. As sure as you've been basking in the attention of being the primary male, you can be sure that someother guy is just waiting to whip the tongs and apron from you and take your position. Remember, no-one looks at the guy who is slicing the bread.

==== BarbedWire ====

BarbedWire consists of twisted pairs of steel cable with sharp exposed points, designed to be used as fencing. It can be quickly errected by stapling lengths of BarbedWire to fence posts, or dispensing rolls of it accross battlefields - such as was done in the [[WorldWarI first]] and [[WorldWarII second]] world wars.

Approached carefully, BarbedWire acts as a barrier to humans and animals. Approached recklessly, BarbedWire can cause entrapment or severe injuries, particularly if the victim continues to struggle against it. Horses are particularly vulnerable to panicking and furthering injury in BarbedWire.

When laying BarbedWire in warfare, it is best not to try to completely block the passage of enemy infantry (which, in the end, is impossible) but simply to delay them and redirect them through the routes that can be best covered with machine gun fire.

RazorWire is a more vicious kind of BarbedWire designed to discourage humans, in particular, from climbing fences.

Very useful. Compare and contrast BarbWire, a useless film.

==== RazorWire ====

RazorWire is a particularly vicious variant of BarbedWire which is used to guard the top of fences and discourage humans from climbing them. Rather than a series of distributed sharp barbs, RazorWire is sharp along it's entire surface, making it almost impossible to find a safe point to grip. It is significantly harder to errect than BarbedWire, and protective gauntlets are required.

==== [[Tax]] ====

[[Tax]] is a mandatory fee paid to the state by an entity, theoretically in exchange for state services. Taxes in the UnitedKingdom include:

~- IncomeTax
~- CouncilTax (assuming the LiberalDemocrats don't take power)
~- [[ValueAddedTax VAT]]
~- InheritanceTax

In the [[UnitedKingdom UK]], national taxes are handled by the InlandRevenue.

==== InlandRevenue ====

In the [[UnitedKingdom UK]], the InlandRevenue are best known for being responsible for:

~- Collection of IncomeTax
~- Assessment of eligibility for state financial aid
~- Collection of NationalInsurance
~- Regulation of companies and charities (through CompaniesHouse)

==== IncomeTax ====

IncomeTax is perhaps the best-known and most popular means of [[Tax taxing]] the populace of your country. It typically involves assessing the income of individuals, seperating them in to one of a number of bands, and charging them a percentage of their income as specified by the band they are in.

Incorrect spelling of ReferentialIntegrity. See ReferentialIntegrity

===ReferentialIntegrity===

In DataBase theory, ReferentialIntegrity is a bit like duct tape. It's kept together by good tabular relationships, and can be broken by people deleting records without regard to the consequences.

For example, if somebody went into the back-end of the database and deleted a page, for example, "ThePopeIsDead", this would cause a problem, because [[MisterJTA]]'s comment on that page was not deleted - it would be left "in the ether", and would be impossible to correct (even by MisterJTA, who should be able to delete his own comments) without **another** trip to the back-end of the database.

Just an example.

===== In Memory =====

=== Of The Time That People Used To Think... ===

=== ...That Deleting [[WikiPage WikiPages]] Was A Good Idea... ===

=== ...Which It Isn't. ===

// - DanHuntley//

[[Nestle]] are a large, multi-national, name-changing organisation who sell [[Foodstuffs]] to people.

What they also do is make powdered milk. They make lots of powdered milk. One day [[Paedophiles paediatricians]] started to tell people that breast milk was better for babies than powdered milk. They weren't just saying this; they had lots of impressive numbers and words with which to back it up. This left Nestle with lots of powdered milk that they couldn't sell to people in the WesternWorld because most of the ones with kids also had [[Tits tits]] too. So they started looking around for people who didn't know that powdered milk wasn't as good for babies as breast milk. They found them on a rather large continent predominantly populated by black people called Africa. Now parts of Africa are not as well developed in terms of infrastructure as the WesternWorld and so some people are less well educated and will believe, as most people will, anything told to them by someone in authority. Nestle went to some of these people and tried to sell them powdered milk but since they weren't [[Americans a people who would buy any old tat simply to own it]] they asked why they should buy powdered milk when it came out of their jubbly bits for free?

This is where Nestle turn into [[Bastards bastards]].

They said that powdered milk was better for babies than breast milk in contravention of the //International Code of Marketing Breast-milk Substitutes//. Many people believed this and so bought the powdered milk. Powdered milk requires water to reconstitute it and in parts of Africa water can be hard to come by. Since the parents wanted their children to be healthy they would use what little clean water they had to make up an inferior substitute for breast milk to feed to their babies. This would leave the parents either without clean water or sometimes without any water at all and also, since they were no longer using their breast milk, they stopped lactating as well.

Nestle's lies led to many deaths, both of children and parents, and also affected the development of the children's immune systems.

The [[StudentsUnion NUS]] were one of the groups to actually do something when they heard about this rather than going 'meh'. They banned all Nestle goods from Student Unions and wrote many petitions. The Nestle boycot is international and was first brought into effect in the US by //[[http://www.infactcanada.ca/InfactHomePage.htm INFACT]]// but the problem was highlighted by the //War On Want// who are affiliated to the international group //SOLIDAR//, all of whom are areligious and apolitical.

The problem is that Nestle are  big. Huge in fact. They won't care that a small group within society have banned the products of one of their divisions from a limited number of retail outlets that usually only have a select customer base anyway.

Thankfully the point of a boycott is not to harm a company's profits but is a)to draw attention to the issue and b)to create a PR problem for the company. The [[StudentsUnion NUS]] boycott is clearly effective in this respect as most people reading this page probably first heard about this issue because of it.

But Nestle are still bastards.

Which you didn't. It's like talking about PIN numbers, where the N stands for number. Muppets.

GarethBowker also adds: or Windows 2000, built on NT Technology, where NT stood for New Technology. Fucking idiots.

DanHuntley adds that he knows it pretty much by heart, and that HTTPProtocol was chosen as the WikiWord very deliberately and with forethought, because HTTProtocol (a) looks shit and (b) confuses people and HTTP wasn't suitable for use as a WikiWord when the link was made.
----
=== Simplicity ===

Client: Hey there, server. I'd like a particular page.
Client: I'm a copy of MozillaFirefox, by the way, and I found you from a link from [[Google]].
Client: I might want something else in a moment, so hang on.
Server: Okay then, here's the page you wanted //<hands>//.
Client: The page has an image on it, has the image changed since I saw it last week?
Server: Nope, same one since last year, you don't need a new copy.
Client: How about this Java Applet; that's new, right?
Server: Yup, here it is. //<hands>//
...
Server: Hmm... guess that client has gone away elsewhere, now. Who's next?
----
=== Denial of Service ===

Everyone's heard of Denial of Service attacks. And the "Simplicity" example shows how a basic one can be achieved. See the "...", while the server waits? Yes. You don't tell it you're done, it waits for a defined length of time. The problem is the server can only deal with so many requests at once, so if you keep it waiting by making zillions of requests at once, genuine ones can't get through. Of course, if it was made so the server drops the connection ASAP that would go some way towards fixing it, but then it becomes really inefficient because you have to go through the first 3 lines every single time you do anything...

Novelty Records. Typically one-hit wonders. Worse, they often have the intention of *being* one-hit wonders, so they scar you for life and then vanish without a trace. The main way to tell the difference is that Novelty Record makers don't usually take it too seriously, and don't do this sort of thing for a day job (TheLaughingGnome excluded). Here is a rough guide:

~- Don't have an existing musical career
~- Don't release an album
~- Begins with "The"
~- Is a collaberation
~- Is a charity event
~- Is humourous
~- Is a Christmas song
~- Is a football song
~- Is from Europe
~- Is largely instrumental
~- Is based on a cult phenomenon (usually from the Internet)
~- Is very succesful

Answer three or more and it's probably a Novelty Record rather than a one-hit wonder. Note - not exact science, your mileage may vary

[[ComputerScienceStudents Compscis]], please don't flame me for over simplifying, or being "not-quite" correct. I've tried to avoid using jargon where possible and make it as easy to understand as possible - [[PaulMann Paul]]

An OperatingSystem is a low-level [[API]] designed to allow a programmer or user to manipulate the physical hardware without having to know exactly how it works

The term has become very vague in recent years, particularly when products like WindowsMe came around

Basic components of an OperatingSystem are as follows:

~- A memory module, designed to allocate physical memory to programs, keep track of it, and prevent them overwriting each others memory

~- A task scheduler, which allows the running of more than one program and distributes CPU time as it sees fit

~- An I/O interface of some kind. This could be keyboard input or disk access in certain circumstances

These form what is known as the kernel

Everything else could be termed an OperatingEnvironment, or an addition to the OperatingSystem, but not an OS itself. There are of course exceptions, and some OSs like Linux include networking, which may be a seperate module in others

Application Programming Interface

An abstract way of talking to a computer using metaphors

For example, if you want to delete a file in DOS, you would type

**del [name of file]**

In Windows, you might drag it to a trashcan. 

The idea is that you don't have to know how the hardware works to use it. This is why [[OperatingSystem Operating Systems]] were invented. Then we invented [[OperatingEnvironment OperatingEnvironments]] to talk to them, and now with the help of [[OperatingSystem OSs]] like MacOs, no-one really knows what's going on any more. It may be easy to use, but it does explain why your 3Ghz PC don't fundamentally move quicker than an 8Mhz AtariSt back in the early 90s

A term which isn't used much anymore, and leads to bizarre things like lecturers declaring that all of the following are [[OperatingSystem Operating Systems]]:

[[Emacs]]
[[Java]] Virtual Machine
MozillaFirefox
[[Windows]] XP

An Operating Environment is a user-interface for an OperatingSystem. The best example of which is Windows 95. It's actually DOS, with a nice happy graphical front-end for the user to work with. The actual OperatingSystem is still DOS (Albeit DOS 7, which only shipped with Windows 95/8)

A command-line is generally not regarded as an OE as you have to have some way of communicating with the computer

Most [[distributions]] of Linux are a combinational OperatingSystem / OperatingEnvironment, with your OE being [[X]], and that in turn being controlled by (typically) either [[Gnome]] or [[KDE]]

OSs which don't have built in graphical OEs:

Windows 95/98 (although it came with one)
DOS (Windows 3.11 was sold as an OE)
*nix (although it usually comes with one)
MacOS X (although it comes with one)
TOS (The AtariSt operating system. Although it came with GEM on the TOS-chip, it was possible to boot without using GEM to save a few extra Kb of memory)

There are very few OSs with a built in graphical OE. A few that spring to mind are:

MacOs (Prior to ten)
AmigaOs (Even though the default startup was a [[CLI]], the command 'loadwb' did not start a seperate program, it merely invoked the menu/icon part of the GUI, since the mouse and windows were already running)
WindowsXP (And WindowsNT) (Load one of these in "command line" mode, and it still invokes the GUI, albeit in a cut-down form)

Of course, you could argue that they are 'graphical sub-systems', but then you're just being picky and would probably say that disk-access wasn't part of an OperatingSystem. Loser.

Cheap home computer of the early 90s. Available in the following forms:

Atari 520 (512k RAM) ST/STF/STM/STFM/STE
Atari 1040 (1024k of RAM) (STFM/STE)
Mega-ST (2Mb of 4Mb of RAM)
Mega-TT (2Mb or 4Mb of RAM)
Stacy (B/W Laptop)
Falcon

Any other Atari products (eg the Atari 400) may look vaguely similar, but they are not.

Operating System simply called TOS (The Operating System). Looked almost identical from 1.00 to 2.06

====Atari 520/1040====
This is what everyone usually means when they refer to the AtariSt, since they were by far the most popular

ST was the original incarnation, and had no TV modulator (monitor only) and no built in disk drive (external only)
STF came with a built in disk drive
STM came with a built in modulator
STFM came with both, and was the most popular (TOS 1.4)
STE had a few new tweaks, such as an updated OS, a [[blitter]], better [[hard drive]] support, stereo sound (with better support for samples), and just to be awkward they moved the video register, causing some 20% of existing software to not work properly... (TOS 1.6/1.62)

Built in MIDI ports. Crap Yamaha bleepy chip thing (1Mhz). Even in the case of the STE, the samples are forced through the YM-2149 (I think) chip, just now in stereo. Woo. This chip also controlled the disk I/O, so incorrect direct hardware access could damage a disk you had in the drive. Yay

Mostly created because Atari were jealous of the [[Amiga Amiga's]] success. They removed all the custom chips and to make up for this, they overclocked the CPU from 7.14Mhz to 8Mhz. Great job guys

STFMs had hard soldered RAM chips, whereas the STE used SIMMs

====Mega ST/TT====
Came in a box with a seperate keyboard. Monitor support only. Either 2mb of RAM or 4. Used quite a lot for DTP work (Calamus) and MIDI work (Cubase), since it was about the only computer around which had built in MIDI ports

The TT ran at 16Mhz, btw

Used TOS 2.05/2.06

====Stacy====
Never came into contact one, but I believe it was a black and white laptop running TOS 2.06

====Falcon====
Atari's last ditch effort to save itself. Quite a nice piece of kit. Came with a meg of RAM, 16Mhz CPU and some really cool direct-hardware graphics stuff. The only Atari capable of playing an MP3 without locking everything else up. Much better sound, which no-one used. Still not as good as an [[Amiga]], but the best piece of software was "Llamazap", by JeffMinter
A scarily popular and seriously expensive SoftSynth package for the PC. Used by [[Weebl]], and quite a few pop-musicians. The new [[Erasure]] was created with it

They're big. You only have so much space

They're expensive. You can only afford a couple, typically

A SoftSynth is a PC emulation of a real synthesizer. PropellorheadReason is the best known example of one. Features a dozen or so real-world synthesizers. Click the buttons, drag the knobs, connect cables as if it were real. Scary stuff...

No, there is no such thing as an [[analogue]] SoftSynth

A lossly compression format.

That's it. There is nothing more to it. It is not illegal to own or make them. It is not illegal to listen to them. It is not illegal to transport or swap them. Got that?

The issue is what they actually contain. That's beyond the scope of this entry, although it is illegal in most of the western world to trade copyrighted material without royalty payments. It just so happens that MP3s are a handy way of doing this, due to the fact it reduces the file size
----
Now the techy bit

MP3 is an encoding and decoding algorithm held by the [[Fascists Fraunhoffer Institute]]. To use the official methods, a royalty fee must be paid. The MP3 encoder and decoder which come with Windows are official. The decoder in WinAMP isn't. Because through a process known as reverse engineering it's possibly to make a different algorithm which does approximately the same thing. The LAME encoder is an unofficial encoder. In some countries such as the US (Thanks to the [[DMCA]]), you can't reverse engineer, and so it's TechnicallyIllegal

MP3s are headerless, so an MP3 file is just a stream of MP3 data with no discernable beginning or end (let's ignore ID3 tags for now)

If you cap one with a Windows PCM ("Wave") header, then you can use DirectShow to play them back, which is how you can get MP3s to play on the likes of Windows 98 with no extra software. However, this seriously confuses devices like [[iPod portable MP3 players]]

See also OggVorbis

Swapping recordings of things which are still technically under copyright, but which the creators have either disowned, or turn a blind eye to because they know they're not going to make any money from it.

MysteryScienceTheatre falls into the second catagory, as long as you don't swap tapes which have been commercially released

Translation:

Yes, it's illegal. But try proving it, or catch us doing it

See FairUse, [[MP3]]s, [[Abandonware]] and TapeTrading

Trading of [[software]] which is still technically under copyright, but which the owner has either disowned, or turns a blind eye to

~- Beneath A Steel Sky is now abandonware, as Revolution have released it into the public domain
~- Grand Theft Auto Vice City is NOT
~- DukeNukem 3D is NOT. Despite the source code being released to the public for free use, the graphics, sound, routines and maps still belong to 3D Realms. So don't steal. Buy it.

Something which the US have a dim view of thanks to the [[DMCA]]

Basically, it means you can make a copy for your own use. If you own the CD, you can make a tape of it to put in the car. Or an [[MP3]] to listen to on your [[iPod]]

It does NOT mean that you can sell the original. Nice try

A messy piece of legislature. Europe is quite close to having it's own, but it keeps being overturned

What does it mean for you? Well, basically it means that you're not allowed to circumvent any kind of copy protection on anything you own, even if you want to apply FairUse laws

This means you can't crack your DigiBox to get free channels. Fair enough

It also means you can't watch your DVDs through anything but an official DVD Player (Official players like Cinemaster, Windvd and Powerdvd pay a license fee). No more Linux player. No more ripping it to your hard drive. That's illegal, dontcha know?

You can't circumvent the protection on ProtectedMusicCds in order to make an MP3 for your _own use_

Or you'll go to jail. Hooray for the [[America land of the free!]]

This one describes the specification for an AudioCd. Bitrate, bit layout, resolution, everything

1/75 (2352-bit) second long bursts of 44.1Khz/16-bit/2 channel PCM audio if you're interested...

You might know this one better as a CD-ROM

One of the RainbowBooks

This one tells you how to make a CD-R or CD-RW

CD+G. Karaoke CDs. Enhanced CDsThat kind of thing

Most CD players only see the first [[session]] of a CD, so we do this:

First session - Practically identical to RedBook, but includes a [[subcode]] track which contains the lyrics

Then a gap of about 30Mb

Second session - Same as YellowBook, but must have certain directories and files, such as an identifier. Can include simple photo galleries

One of the RainbowBooks

This one describes how to make a VideoCd.

Mode 2/XA MPEG-1 encoded video at 352x288/25fps or 352x240/29.97fps at 1.13Mbit/s, with 224kbit 44.1khz/16-bit/2 channel MPEG-1 layer 2 audio to be precise

Includes support for additional language tracks, but no-one ever uses them. Except for a couple of karaoke CDs maybe

Can also include a primitive one-level menu system

One of the RainbowBooks

Photo CD. Very copyrighted. Includes some things like each photo must be in JPG format at a number of different resolutions, to allow for magnification with no CPU overhead. Very dependant on multi-[[session]]

One of the RainbowBooks

CD-I discs. Quite peculiar. Like a cross between the YellowBook CD-ROM standard, and the RedBook audio cd standard. Must have certain directories including some executable code for the player to run. Can features menus, videos, audio and suchlike

A series of standards defined by Philips describing how CDs are made

GreenBook
BeigeBook
WhiteBook
BlueBook
OrangeBook
YellowBook
RedBook

There is also a purple book describing "double-density CDs", but this was abandoned in favour of DVDs, which doesn't follow a rainbow book

A breach of the RedBook standard. Take it back. It doesn't meet the standard for music cds, and there's no guarantee it'll work with your CD player

//Recently, some major recording publishers have begun to sell discs that violate the Red Book standard for the purposes of copy prevention. Philips has warned them that including the Compact Disc Digital Audio logo on such non-conforming discs may constitute trademark infringement; either in anticipation or in response, the long-familiar logo is no longer to be seen on many recent CDs.// - [[Wikipedia]]

Digital Rights Management

In fact, that's a lie to begin with. It's sole purpose is to restrict your rights on what you can do with your music

For example, one aspect might say you can play a song only a certain number of times, or at a lower bitrate unless you pay for it, or only on a certain number of devices, or you can't copy it

It's a nice idea, but suffers from severely flawed implementation

For example, with some DRM, if you format your hard drive or move to a new computer, you can't take your songs with you (A lot of online stores now let you download files as often as you like, to circumvent this problem)

Or you can listen to them, but if you want to put them onto your portable music player, you have to pay again

DRM files require a DRM-enabled player. WinAMP won't work. You *have* to use Windows Media Player to play WMA/DRM files. Or how about the only portable player allowed to decrypt iTunes songs is... the iPod?

Some DRM files do sneaky stuff. For example, I have a 5.1 system connected via digital-output to my sound card. Since PCs are "noisy" environments, I decode my digital files outside the box to get a clearer signal. When playing WMA/DRM, Microsoft turn off the digital out from my soundcard. Thanks guys.

The StudentsUnion, or less commonly, the 'NUS', describes itself as:

//"...a voluntary membership organisation comprising a confederation of local student representative organisations in colleges and universities throughout the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland which have chosen to affiliate and which pay a membership fee. We have nearly 750 constituent members (CMs)"//

In reality, (personal opinion alert) it's a mis-managed drinking club, which has as little as possible to do with actual students. This way, they don't have to spend too much money. Which means this money can be spent on the pet-projects of whichever trumped-up little politico that happens to be in charge at the time.

~-The main argument put forward for membership of the NUS is gaining "national representation" for students. It's a nice idea, but in reality the NUS doesn't faithfully or effectively represent the interests of its members. 
~-The NUS National Executive Committee is elected only by delegates to the NUS National Conference - who usually represent a political party or special interest group rather than the typical student.
~-For example, it was lobbying by the Aldwych Group - a campaigning group of independent student unions from 12 UK universities - that put an end to plans to charge 'top-up' tuition fees. Scottish politicians scrapped tuition fees after a campaign by Scottish student unions - who aren't NUS members. In both cases, the NUS tried to take the credit.
~-Students are best represented by people whose sole objective is to promote the interests of the student body, not by those who wish to use the NUS as a springboard to a lifetime in politics. 

==Beer and Food==

~-The NUS doesn't deal with the Carlsberg-Tetley Group, which means no Carlsberg Export. 
~-Indeed, it only deals with it's favoured bulk-purchasers - which means no RealAle for BeerSnobs. 
~-The same goes for chocolate - the NUS has fallen out with [[Nestle]], so they want us to ban all Nestle products - [[KitKat Kit-Kats]], for fucks sake. This is hardly a good use of a sabbatical's time, is it?

Is this ridiculously false political machine really worth the 35,000/year membership fee?

It should be said that the NUS and the StudentsUnion are two linked, but different things. The StudentsUnion can also refer to the building on the PenglaisCampus of [[UniversityOfWalesAberystwyth UWA]] that houses the Union offices, the Union shop, [[9Bar9]] and TheJoint. Pink noise has a spectral frequency of 1/f and is found mostly in nature. It is the most natural sounding of the noises. By equalizing the sounds, you can generate rainfall, waterfalls, wind, rushing river, and other natural sounds. 

Pink noise is exactly between brown and white noise (which is why some people used to call it tan noise, but pink was more appealing). It is neither random nor predictable. It has a fractal-like nature when viewed. When zoomed in, the pattern looks identical to when zoomed out, except at a lower amplitude.

The entire knowledge of the universe with a lot of useless facts thrown in.

On one side there are the forces of good - [[Human humans]], [[Elves elves]] and [[Dwarfs dwarfs]]. On the other there are the forces of evil - [[Goblins goblins]], [[Ogres ogres]], [[Trolls trolls]] and [[Orcs orcs]]. Of all the noxious inhuman creatures an adventurer must overcome during his quests for fame and fortune, orcs will always be the most frequent of his adversaries. Orcs infest almost everywhere, though they prefer dark underground regions: like [[Goblins goblins]], they dislike sunlight. They are squat, ugly brutes, shorter than a man, but taller than a [[Goblins goblin]]. They have warty brown-green skins, usually covered in a motley assortment of skins, furs and irregular scraps of armour scavenged from previous opponents. Their favourite weapons are serrated swords, whips, flails, morning stars and spears.

Orcs are disgusting, filthy creatures with vile habits to match. They delight in the pain of others, even weaker members of their own race, and they will torture their captives before setting them to work as slaves. The living-quarters of an orc stronghold will be knee-deep in filth and muck, and will be very unhealthy, to say the least. Orcs delight in unsavoury activities. Their favourite food, for example, is a rare dish called [[Elves elf]] intestines in [[Gnomes]]-blood sauce, though when this is out of season trhey have to settle for more mundane delights like rat-gizzard soup, or curried bat surprise.

The armies of the orcs are led by **Great Orcs**. Larger and stronger than common orcs, they are possibly the result of selective breeding with [[Trolls]]. If more than four orcs are encountered, chances are a Great Orc will be lurking nearby. If one is present, it will keep the rest from squabbling and brawling with one another. Orcs are argumentative beasts, who seem to spend more of their time fighting amoung themselves than against the dreaded [[Elves]] and [[Dwarfs]].

Like all the chaotic races, some unfortunate orcs are mutants, with an amazing assortment of deficiencies. They may have strange skins, elongated or shortened limbs, or special powers, such as flying, telepathy and so on. Most mutants are despised by most normal orcs, who treat them as if they were slaves, or mangy dogs suitable only for kicking and beating.

Sskahryl is a [[dragon Gold Dragon]] currently residing at NaNeis, where the [[Samaritans]] shop used to be. Although for some reason he is coloured black. This may be due to him being outdoors for long periods of time. The nice lady at NaNeis told me he has spend a lot of time as an outdoor water feature, which I found somewhat disturbing...

The nice lady at NaNeis now knows that we seek the release of Sskahryl, so it's only a matter of time now..

There are some races which were roaming the [[Earth]] when man was still [[Evolution swinging in the trees]]. Nowadays most of them, especially [[Elves]], keep out of men's affairs as much as they are able. The Dwarfs, however, have long learnt to live alongside the younger race, who recognise them as doughty warriors and skilled craftsmen. In many settlements they even live alongside men, though they favour living underground

A typical Dwarf stands only about a metre tall, yet looks a good deal older than the [[human humans]] who tower over him. Their faces are wrinkled and weather-beaten, usually somewhere between ruddy-pink and brown. Their fashion is for long bushy beards, some of which are so long they need to be plaited and wrapped around their waists like belts. Their clothes are made from fine worked leather, though these will usually be covered with light jerkins of strong mail. Their favourite weapons are battleaxes, war-hammers and other hewing weapons, for they are skilled at mining and stone-working as well as fighting.

Dwarfs are fond of ale, pipe tobacco and a good tale of heroic deeds. They are not so fond of over-hasty people, preferring to take life steadily and calmly. Sometimes quick to anger if slighted by an ill-mannered human, they are not adverse to teaching some manners. They can be very honourable beings however, and they appreciate bravery and good fighting. They despite [[Orcs]], [[Goblins]] and other cruel cowardly beings, and stories of their interminable wars deep under the earth are frequent. Above all, Dwarfs love precious jewels and metals, and they spend much of their time mining them from the [[earth]] before jealously hoarding them away from potential thieves

----
[[CategoryCreatures List of all creatures]]

**Trolls** are large, ugly humanoids related to [[Ogres]], [[Orcs]], [[Goblins]] and a variety of lesser cross-breeds. They many be found in many lands, but always doing what they most enjoy - being thoroughly evil! From civilized Troll mercenaries to savage Hill Trolls, these creatures delight in torture, death and worse. There are a number of different types of Troll, found in different areas of the world

Violent, stupid and thus very dangerous, **Cave Trolls** are the most primitive of all Troll races. They tend to be leaner than other Trolls, their bodies lithe and muscular with long arms that end in sharpened claws. They are uglier, if that is possible, than Common Trolls, and their teeth are far larger, sticking out more like tusks from their drooling mouths. They are solitary, unsociable creatures, usually found hiding from daylight in a dark cave or passage deep underground. They are exclusively carnivorous and delight in the tender flesh of [[human humans]], but more often have to settle for stringy rat meat. Their favourite weapons are clubs and long knives, though their talons are just as effective. They hoard shiny items, attracted by their glitter, and their lairs may be crammed with all manner of glinting things, some valuable

Once living in the wilderness like [[Orcs]], **Common Trolls** are mostly found in the armies of evil, where they can practise their favourite hobbies against puny humans. There are still a few primitive tribes of Common Trolls living in rough villages in the wildlands, but even they are considerably more civilized (as Trolls go) than the average Hill or Cave Troll. If a more primitive Common Troll is encountered, it will fortunately be less skillful in battle, for it will not have had the benefit of military training. Whatever their circumstances, Common Trolls are usually large and fat, taller than a [[human]] by about a head, with ugly faces and muscular limbs. They are gruff and surly creatures, but they enjoy jokes in which other beings get severely injured. Their favourite weapons are large battle-axes and war-hammers

The interminable wars between the [[Dwarfs]] and the **Hill Trolls** have continued since before history was recorded, for the two races loathe each other. Hill Trolls are warlike beings, who provide endless hazards to travellers and settlers in the higher regions. They are the largest of all Trolls, usually dressed in furs and leathers, their long hair braided with bones and jewellery. Their favourite weapons are spears and battle-axes, and they also use shields and odd scraps of armour to protect themselves. They dwell in tribal villages high in the hills, from where they can sweep down into the valleys to attack the settlements of [[Dwarfs]] and [[human humans]] alike. They don't like goats much either

**Sea Trolls** dwell in large bodies of water, from deep oceans to inland lakes. They have scaly green skins, webbed hands and feet, and gills in their necks, but otherwise look much like Cave Trolls. They live on fish, but occasionally manage to overturn a boat or pluck a tasty [[human]] from a riverbank. They can only survive in air for a few minutes, but that is usually enough for them to grab someone with their claws, bite depply into his neck, and leap back in to the water with him. They are hated by Merfolk, who will try to kill the things if they stray too near to their territory. Sea Trolls make their lairs in underwater caves, often hiding them with weed for protection. Inside there may be many relics of their past victims, both bones and treasure.

PresidentBartlet is the fictional President of the United States, portrayed by MartinSheen in TheWestWing. 

From NBC.com:
"After serving three terms as a U.S. Congressman and two terms as the Governor of New Hampshire, Josiah "Jed" Bartlet realized his dream of becoming President of the United States of America. A deeply religious man, President Bartlet attended Notre Dame University with the thought of becoming a priest. After deciding against that, Bartlet received a PhD in Economics from the London School of Economics. As President, he often slides into the role of professor and mentor, and still turns to God for advice when facing any kind of crisis. He's been married to the First Lady, Abigail, for thirty-two years and they have three daughters, Liz, Ellie and Zoey. Barlet claims he is a direct descendant of one of the original signers of the Declaration of Independence. The President recently revealed to his staff and the American public that he has multiple sclerosis."

====Overview====
Of all the frightful, terrifying and downright awesome beings that stalk the [[Earth]], none are as powerful as the dragons. Some say the race of Dragonkind is as old as time itself; there were certainly Dragons around to be recorded in the first histories of mankind. In the past the old civilizations were great allies of the Dragons, and they shared much knowledge. Young Dragons allowed themselves to be ridden by humans, even in battle, where their combined powers helped drive the armies of Chaos and Evil back under the ground.

Nowadays the old Dragons hide themselves away, sleeping out the millennia until civilization needs them again. Younger Dragons still stalk the [[Earth]], but many are evil creatures, concerned only with acquiring gold and treasure. In some of the newer kingdoms there are people who have never seen a Dragon, for they are now very rare creatures.

Dragons are the noblest of all reptilian races, gigantic winged creatures with long necks and tails. There are many subspecies, each with its own skin colour and other individual species. All Dragons can fly, and most can speak a wide variety of [[human]] and animal languages. Dragons are able to spit fire, acid or ice from their mouths. They also have claws and fangs; even without their fatal breath they would be more than a match for the strongest opponents. They come in different sizes and strengths, according to their age. Dragons seem to be all but immortal, and they mature only very slowly. Dragons are called young between the time they burst out of the egg and reach one hundred years of age, by which time they may have grown up to twelve metres long. They are impetuous, as Dragons go, and may be encountered in partnership with a powerful [[human]] such as a sorceror or evil leader who can provide both protection and regular food. Young Dragons do not know much of magic or books, as they are far too busy acquiring treasure to learn from wizards or converse with sages.

====Misconceptions====
~- Dragons are not always red
~- Not all dragons hoard treasure
~- Not all dragons are sentient
~- Not all dragons hate [[human humans]]
~- Not all dragons can breathe fire
~- Not all dragons are magical to the extent of Brass Dragons

====Life====
Adult Dragons are aged between one hundred and five hundred years old, and can grow up to about twenty-five metres in length. There are very few adults known to mankind, for they are very rare and spend much of their time sleeping on their vast hoards in cavernous halls deep below a mountain or castle.

Old Dragons have not been seen by anyone for many hundreds of years, and it is thought they may have left this earth to live on the MagicalPlanes in peace. For this reason there are no details of them in the following descriptions. It is very unlikely they will be encountered by adventurers on the EarthlyPlane.

The skin of a Dragon will easily fetch a pretty price, whereupon it can be used by skilled craftsmen to make superb armour. Actually acquiring the skin of a Dragon is another matter. Plus, it's cruel.

A wet start to August usually means a good breeding season for Dragons, who will hatch sometime the following summer. Dragons have the curious habit of consuming foliage from chestnut trees where available, shortly after sunrise. Leaves consumed at this time do not travel down the normal digestive tract, but go instead into a second stomach set forward and a little below that which the Dragon uses to digest food. Here, in this second stomach, the leaves are converted into sedimentary layers of humus which, encouraged by the Dragon's body heat, gives off vast quantities of methane gas. Once a Dragon is four months old, it develops crystalline extrusions on its upper fangs and a thin layer of natural metallic capping on the lower. The result of these developments is that when the dragon snaps its jaws together sharply, it produces a spark. This spark will normally ignite the almost continuous flow of methane from the second stomach, producing a the fiery dragon breath which is such a distinctive feature for those breeds which produce it.

====European Dragons vs Eastern Dragons====
When most people think of dragons, they think of the European dragon. However, the eastern dragon has deeper roots in mythology. Typically an Eastern dragon will be amiable to [[human humans]], whereas a European dragon won't be. Eastern dragons also don't usually have legs, and tend to represent earth spirits, such as water

====Common Types of Dragon====
**Black Dragons** are usually encountered in rough, hilly terrain, where they may be preying upon villages for their livestock or people. Both young and adult Black Dragons make their lairs in caverns, to which they will return after a day's hunting. Younger creatures will have only a small, cramped cave, but an adult may occupy a vast cavern complex, housing a tribe of [[Goblins]] or [[Orcs]] as well as various other monsters, with several secret entrances for when danger threatens. Doesn't breathe fire, but can breathe a cloud of poisonous gas. Young creatures can create one up to three metres in diameter, an adult twice that.

**Brass Dragons** have yet to be confirmed by many sources, for reasons given later. All people can agree on is that they are very bad news indeed. There have only been five authenticated appearances of Brass Dragons in the whole of recorded [[human]] history: two in Asia, one in Europe, one in Spain and one which turned up in Londinium before the Romans left. In every instance, the destruction wrought was massive. Three-quarters of Londinium was demolished or ravaged by fire, and seventeen of the very finest Roman Legions completely wiped out before the beast stupidly consumed the entire stock of an ale-house and drowned after falling drunkenly into the Thames. While the natural history of other breeds is relatively well known, no-one really has the last idea where Brass Dragons come from, what laws govern their abrupt appearance, or how to get rid of them when they do appear. Typically, a Brass Dragon will turn up out of the blue, run riot for several months or years, and then simply disappear (The Drowned Dragon of Londinium was unusual in the way it met its fate). No-one has ever succeeded in killing one. One reason for this noteworthy failure is that there is every indication Brass Dragons may be magical. 

The largest and noblest of all their race, **Gold Dragons** are only rarely encountered by [[human humans]]. They prefer to inhabit large towers or castles in the middle of deserts or at the top of mountains, well removed from most other creatures. They are better disposed towards [[human humans]] than other Dragons, though they cannot understand that their short lifespan makes them seem impatient and rude. Gold Dragons tend to be especially friendly with sages and sorcerors, who sometimes visit them with questions on ancient history and magic. The Dragons dislike the more primitive and violent humanoid races, though, and will normally attack them on sight. Gold Dragons can breathe a wide jet of flame, broad enough to hit two opponents. Creatures aged more than about seventy years may also have magical spells to back up their claws and teeth; they are particularly fond of illusions and tricks. The armoured hide of a Gold Dragon is very tough.

A young **Green Dragon** may be encountered amid the tangles at the centre of a large forest, where it will make its lair in an old ruin or a shallow cave in a hillside. An adult creature will only be encountered deep in a tropical jungle, well away from any settlements, where it can enjoy being the largest and most voracious predator in the region. Green Dragons are natural hunters, both quick and cunning, and make fearsome opponents. They can breathe out a thin stream of fire, adults causing more damage than youngsters.

**Red Dragons** are hoarders who relish collecting coins, jewels and all other valuable items. When encountered, a Red Dragon will usually be in its cavern, sprawled across the top of a large pile of treasure. Red Dragons are automatically suspicious of anyone they encounter, believing them to be thieves intent on stealing their treasure, and will attack them immediately. They can shoot fire-balls from their mouths, which they send roaring through the air to explode on their target, and can shoot them up to twenty-five metres with surprising accuracy. This is the type of Dragon most frequently portrayed in Western Fiction.

**Silver Dragons** have long been the arch-enemies of their Gold cousins, for they are very jealous of their status among the rest of Dragonkind. They seem to be perpeptually plotting against their noble relations, though events rarely get violent. Silver Dragons live in desolate areas away from other creatures, for they can be bad-tempered and aggressive. In an attack a Silver Dragon can shoot out a chilling sheet of cold that is wide enough to hit two opponents at once. Silver Dragons fear fire though, and would rather give away part of their vast treasure-hoard than face several creatures wielding it against them.

Of all the desolate, inhospitable places that Dragons inhabit, nowhere is worse than that of the **White Dragons**. They can only survive in sub-zero temperatures, so they will only ever be encountered amid the snow and ice of the extreme North or South. They dwell in vast caves or castles carved from the ice itself. They are the most unpredictable of all Dragons, and will normally eat any being they come across. In keeping with its frigid home, a White Dragon can breathe out a stream of ice that will freeze its opponent. A White Dragon will not eat its dead prey straight away. Sometimes, especially when the long winter draws near, they will leave the bodies inside large blocks of ice, to keep until other food is scarce, when they will claw them out and eat them at their leisure.

See also [[Cinerus]] and [[Sskahryl]]

Manticores were created centuries ago by an insane warlock from places unknown, fooling with things that should have been left well alone. Using powerful magic, he mixed a lion, a scorpion and a bat together with a human and created the first Manticore. He repeated the experiment many times, until he was finally killed by one of his creations. Since then the monstrosities have scattered into the most inhospitable parts of the world, where their evil natures fester with hatred for all life

A Manticore has the head of an old, bearded man, which flows into the mane and then the body of a large lion. From their powerful shoulders a pair of large, leathery bat's wings sprout, and behind them rears a [[scorpion]]-like tail tipped with a sting the size of man's head! They will attack with their claws or their sting, alternately slashing and striking at their opponent. In a Manticore's lair there will be innumerable bones, the sorry relics of its past victims. There may also be some weapons, equipment or treasure, for it cannot digest such hard items, although it does consume the bones of it's victims

{{image class="right" alt="A snake, yesterday" url="http://www.pacifist.co.uk/rock/snake.gif"}}
There is no reason to be afraid of snakes. Most snakes you encounter are not poisonous, and are more scared of you than you are of them. Just leave them alone and stop poking them with sticks and we'll all get along much nicer. Okay?

They are NOT [[BasiliskLizard basilisks]] despite what HarryPotter says. They usually eat birds, insects and eggs. Snake digestion is ridiculously inefficient, absorbing everything except claws and hair. They are not slimy, but they are cold-blooded. Some snakes can see in Infra-red
{{image class="left" alt="Another snake" url="http://www.pacifist.co.uk/images/mini-DSC00068.JPG"}}
Snakes smell by flicking their tongue to collect airborne particles. If you are bitten by a snake, you can _not_ suck out the venom with your mouth, as the venom will pass through your circulatory system in a matter of seconds. However, of the 7000 Americans who are bitten by snakes each year, less than 15 die. You're more likely to die by eating one and becoming infected with parasites

List of aggressive, venemous snakes: 

~- Cobras
~- Mambas
~- Death Adders
~- Vipers
~- Tiger Snakes
~- Rattle Snakes
~- Coral Snakes

Most of these are _very_ small. The larger ones tend to constrict you instead. But only if they feel threatened or surprised.

{{image src="http://acc6.its.brooklyn.cuny.edu/~phalsall/images/mricci.gif" alt="Missionary" class="left"}} A [[Missionary missionary]] is basically a door-to-door salesman of [[Religion religion]]; frequently [[Christianity]]. These people travel around the world explaining to other people why their religion would win in a fight, or something, meanwhile, people from the place they are visiting are travelling elsewhere, doing the same. The net result is that the only people who actually care about [[Religion religion]] are at any given time at the wrong side of the world in relation to the people who are trying to convert them, and who they are trying to convert, and so [[Missionary missionaries]] will frequently find themselves cooked and eaten by strange tribes in distant places on account of being rather annoying, but really tasty.

Now for a recipe:

//Serves: tribe//

One missionary, medium
Carrots to taste

Boil, [[SpitRoast spit-roast]], fry (ouchie), or otherwise cook the missionary. If the missionary has not already been killed, cook alive to preserve flavour and provide entertainment. Serve on a bed of crushed carrot or in a pie.

[[Microsoft]] was the name given to a particularly bizzare side-show act which enjoyed vast popularity in Ludlow in the seventeenth century. It consisted of a dwarf with a floppy felt hat sewn to his head; the story went that he'd angered a seamstress by refusing to model for her and she had sewn the hat to him as revenge, finishing with a knot on the inside so the stitches couldn't come unpicked.

In 1974 this was proven to be an elementary fake; the enterprising dwarf had simply built a time machine, travelled to the future, befriended an SF make-up artist, and convinced them to draw on the stitches in a convincing way.

The best OperatingSystem [[MicrosoftCorporation Microsoft]] ever made

Why?

~-NTFS. Possibly the best filing system ever invented. More flexible security wise than your average [[Unix]] filing system. Ridiculously fast. Introduced with WindowsNT but most home users didn't use that.
~-Stable. Hark if you will, [[Linux]] users, but every single crash I've had has been due to faulty hardware. Unlike Windows9x, if an application goes wrong, it doesn't tend to bring the whole system down or write into areas it's not meant to
~-Non-fluffy. Unlike WindowsXP where [[MicrosoftCorporation Microsoft]] try to hide all the really useful stuff away, Windows2000 lays it bare. Hardware, domain and user administration are simple to control. So what if it's a graphical interface? That's not a _bad_ thing (except for the possibility it might encourage users to change things they don't really understand), and most networking stuff can be done on the command line if you _really_ want to //(almost everything can be done on the command-line if you really want to - [[DanHuntley Dan]])//
~-Hidden command line. True, command lines are incredibly good for things like pattern recognition (esp. regular expressions), but most humans think in terms of _visual_ things. That's why GUIs are so popular. If you absolutely have to use the command prompt, you can, but you're not forced to
~-No [[Palladium]]. Unlike WindowsXP, there isn't any DRM stuff in Windows2000, unless you install WindowsMediaPlayer (latest version), or ServicePack3 or higher. Even then, it just appears as a service which you can disable //(no [[Palladium]] in any version of Windows at all, actually; DRM only exists in WindowsMediaPlayer, which isn't included in new versions of Windows sold in Europe anyway - [[DanHuntley Dan]])//
~-Intuitive. Believe it or not, the Windows layout has remained almost constant, not just because it's more widely recognised, but because it has a very gradual learning curve. But there's still no excuse for putting "Shutdown" on the "Start" menu
~-Activemovie. The simplest video player known to Windows. You don't need WindowsMediaPlayer. Just type "mplayer2" into the Run command, and have a DirectShow interface. That's it. It works.

There's still no excuse for the following, but you're not forced to use them:

~-IIS. It's a horrible webserver, but at least in the Professional edition it doesn't come switched on
~-System sounds, animated icons, fading windows etc... Fair enough, practically every [[OperatingSystem OS]] has them, but except for the sounds, they aren't turned on by default //(not sure I've ever seen animated icons in an un-hacked Windows system: clarify? - [[DanHuntley Dan]])//

People who use Windows2000:
~- PaulMann

See also WindowsVsLinux

=== Message For Ruth ===

I'd noticed that when you want to create new pages, you often create a WikiWord on this page (the SandBox) in order to create it.

There's no need to do this, you know - just type the page name into the address bar (so to create a page called RuthVarley, supposing one hadn't been created already, you could just append RuthVarley to the http://www.rockmonkey.org.uk/ in the address bar, or even RuthVarley/edit, if you want to go straight into the editor).

On the other hand, it's somewhat bad practice to make WikiPages that are not linked to by any other WikiPage - so making a page by creating a link from the SandBox, then destroying that link, is a little bit rude. This is because you may eventually end up with entirely-disconnected pages, which nobody can ever find out about but which still take up space.

Just a thought...

Hugz; [[DanHuntley Dan]]

[[www.teagames.com/games/chuck/play.php Chuck]] is a fantastic game from the creators of [[www.teagames.com teagames.com]] in which you throw/launch a crash dummy through four different stages, each one as strenuous as the next.  To get a [[http://www.teagames.com/index.php?page=scores_best_chuck_0_0 high score]], you must be able to throw the man the furthest and the most accurately depending on which stage youre on.  

You will have trouble beating my record though, as it is currently the highest score I've personally seen so far.  However, they regularly refresh the score boards and remove high scores, but I managed to take a screen shot of the wonderful result...

Basically [[Schlampe]] is the German word for [[Bitch]], which is the term used generally towards females of a rude, slutty, or plain annoying nature.

e.g. "Kezzie u're such a bitch for tellin Shazza th@ I fancy him"

<Back to SwearWords

The term used for a female dog, but also commonly used as an insult that generally implies some degree of annoyance or nuisance

====RockMonkey Personality Test: Question 3====
----

Something very exciting is happening, like, I don't know, a meteorite has just hit the new Interpol building or something. The whole place is crawling with the press, and sundry excited onlookers. Where are you?

a) [[Test11 Right out at the forefront. You live for moments like this!]]

b) [[Test12 Exiting the scene before the police can catch up with you...]]

c) [[Test21 Composing a letter of complaint to your MP. This is supposed to be a //quiet// area.]]

d) [[Test22 Sleeping. If people want your attention, they should do this sort of thing after 3pm.]]

e) [[Test23 Selling things to the crowd. Somebody's going to make money from this, why shouldn't it be you?]]
