====RockMonkey Personality Test: Question 4====
----

You've just been dumped. What do you do?

a) [[Test161 Cry. Then start making plans for revenge....]]

b) [[Test170 Cry. Then eat chocolate. Then cry again.]]

c) [[Test169 Celebrate. It was all part of your grand scheme.]]

d) [[Test168 Buy lots of porn.]]

e) [[Test167 Go out and find someone new.]]
[[Test6 Go to question 6]]{{SetToken token="q5" value="a"}}
[[Test6 Go to question 6]]{{SetToken token="q5" value="b"}}
[[Test6 Go to question 6]]{{SetToken token="q5" value="c"}}
[[Test6 Go to question 6]]{{SetToken token="q5" value="d"}}
[[Test6 Go to question 6]]{{SetToken token="q5" value="e"}}

====RockMonkey Personality Test: Question 5====
----

The world has just ended, and you are standing before Anubis, god of the dead (yeah, turns out the Egyptians were right - who'd have thought it?). He's just condemned you to spend eternity in the fiery pit. Why?

a) [[Test166 Because you lived a thoroughly disreputable life. Oh well.]]

b) [[Test55 He hasn't got a reason. Everybody picks on you!]]

c) [[Test54 You called him a 'dog-faced twat'. You didn't know he was a god!]]

d) [[Test53 You couldn't afford the bribe.]]

e) [[Test52 You asked him to. All your friends were going there.]]
[[Test7 Go to question 7]]{{SetToken token="q6" value="a"}}
[[Test7 Go to question 7]]{{SetToken token="q6" value="b"}}
[[Test7 Go to question 7]]{{SetToken token="q6" value="c"}}

[[Test7 Go to question 7]]{{SetToken token="q6" value="f"}}

====RockMonkey Personality Test: Question 6====
----
Why, why, why!!!???

a) [[Test51 You cease to interest me. Better questions please!]]

b) [[Test60 Why what?]]

c) [[Test59 Would you like to talk about it?]]

d) [[Test58 Believe me, we've all had days like that.]]

e) [[Test57 I'm confused...]]

f) [[Test56 Because.]]
[[Test8 Go to question 8]]{{SetToken token="q7" value="a"}}
[[Test8 Go to question 8]]{{SetToken token="q7" value="b"}}
[[Test8 Go to question 8]]{{SetToken token="q7" value="c"}}

[[Test8 Go to question 8]]{{SetToken token="q7" value="e"}}

====RockMonkey Personality Test: Question 7====
----

You've really screwed up this time. You've done something so bad, your other half may never forgive you. Something so disgustingly insensitive I can't even bring myself to type it. How do you make it all better?

a) [[Test65 Pretend it was your long-lost twin who committed the terrible offence]]

b) [[Test64 Stick something in the nukerowave, dig out some candles and hope that food will win forgiveness.]]

c) [[Test63 Leave the country and never come back. Better that than being murdered as you sleep!]]

d) [[Test62 Buy everything in Thorntons, 100 tonnes of wrapping paper and a couple of crates of champagne.]]

e) [[Test61 Say your sorry. And mean it. If they can't take the apology, then you'll never win them back.]]

==== KnightmareWikiGame ====

Based on the hit 80's children's TV show [[Knightmare]], this [[WikiGames WikiGame]] is under development by DanHuntley.

So, until you phase with us once more...
----
=== Extra Information ===
//Got questions? Post them here!//

~- **The Adventurers Code:** Please [[KnightmareAdventurersCode read it here]]. You'll play a lot better that way.

~- **System Requirements:** This [[WikiGames WikiGame]] **will not** run in a satisfactory way under [[MicrosoftCorporation Microsoft]] InternetExplorer 6 or below (all released versions at time of writing). **IT REALLY WILL NOT!** You will need a web browser that correctly supports [[CascadingStyleSheets CSS]] and [[PNGFormat PNG]] images. Under InternetExplorer, the game will be pretty much unplayable. The [[WikiGames WikiGame]] will be tested under MozillaFirefox and [[OperaBrowser Opera]], which can be obtained from [[http://www.getfirefox.com/ GetFirefox.com]] and [[http://www.opera.com/ Opera.com]] respectively.

~- **Images Used:** Images used in the game include stills from the series, as broadcast on [[ChallengeTV]], some of which have been edited to, for example, airbrush out dungeoneers and props, which are then dynamically added later.
----
=== Extra Goodies ===

~- [[http://www.scatmania.org/wp-content/KnightmareWikiGame.png 28th April 2005 - Developmental Screenshot]]

==== KnightmareAdventurersCode ====

As used in [[Knightmare]], classic 80's kids TV game show, and in the KnightmareWikiGame:

----
=== The Rules of the Knightmare Dungeon ===

1.  Your Life Force Status has three possible stages: GREEN, AMBER and RED. You begin the adventure on GREEN, indicating that you are unwounded and fresh for the Challenge.

2.  During your adventure you will gradually lose Life Force energy. You may also lose one Life Force grade all together if you make a mistake.

3. You can eat any item of food at any time which will restore your Life Force to GREEN. Your Life Force cannot go above GREEN.

4. You can carry up to two objects at a time. If you find an item which you want but you already have two, you must discard one. Objects from level 1 cannot be used in level 2 and so on.

5. You will sometimes be given spells to use during your adventure. You can only use up to three spells in your quest. Most spells are useful in several situations, but there will usually be one special situation that each spell is particularly helpful in dealing with. Choose the right moment to cast your spell, since a spell can only be used once.

6. Remain true to the Code of Chivalry: be courageous, dutiful and just, protect the weak, and show honour even in adversity.

One final point - the RIGHT-hand path is usually the best path to take, unless you are advised otherwise.
----
With thanks to [[http://www.knightmare.com/ Knightmare.com]].

==== [[ChanServ]] ====

ChanServ is a bot on irc.freenode.net (the server where the RockMonkey ChatRoom is currently hosted). It's purpose is to keep a list of active channels and keep them alive for their registered owners.

It's also there to give OperatorStatus to the channel admins and enforce any channel bans.

[[InternetRelayChat Back to other pages on IRC]]

== General ==

Precursor to modern "Chat rooms".

Since it's worldwide and almost totally anarchic, it has proved quite useful in the past to report world news before the major news companies like [[Reuters]] do. Ner...

The RockMonkey ChatRoom is actually an IRC channel, and the program you use on the website is just a frontend to that

Rules to IRC very simple:

Choose a nickname
Connect to a server
Connect to a channel
Talk

If you connect to a channel that doesn't exist, you create it. If a channel ever becomes empty, it stops existing. Aww... so sad... //(that's not in the RFC; it's server-specific, and it's quite possible within the spec for a channel to exist with no clients, and some IRC servers support stay-open channels - Dan)//

== Bots ==

IRC is full of both people and bots, some are more anoying than others, but there we go...

Bots you might come into contact with include:
	1) [[Igneous]]
	2) ChanServ
	3) NickServ
	4) MemoServ

==== [[NickServ]] ====

NickServ is a bot on irc.freenode.net (the server where the RockMonkey ChatRoom is currently hosted). It's purpose is to keep tabs on who uses what NickNames on the server. You can stop people from stealing your nickname by registering it with NickServ.
 Once you've registered your NickName, you authenticate to the bot and it will give you access to all the privelages you've been given (like OpsStatus in channels).
 
To register a NickName, you need to log into IRC, then do the following:

Give yourself the nickname you want (to make sure it's not already being used)

Register yourself with the command **/msg nickserv register <your-password>**

OPTIONAL: Then send **/msg nickserv set hide email on**

OPTIONAL: And finally **/msg nickserv set email <your-email-address>**

You can set more, such as an alternative nickname, if you want, but you don't have to

Whenever you connect to RockMonkey, send the command **/msg nickserv identify <your-password>** - most IRC clients allow you to define a list of commands to send when you first connect...

Also known as TheJams, TheJustifiedAncientsOfMuMu, [[2K]], TheKFoundation, [[Disco2K Disco 2000]], OneWorldOrchestra and TheTimelords. Side Projects include [[Space]], TheOrb, AdvancedAcousticArmaments, and BlackSmoke

This article is about the music, the stunts and the events of BillDrummond and JimmyCauty using the moniker TheKLF
---------------
**1. Pure trance originals**

Not to be confused with the "Pure Trance Series", envisaged as 10 x 2000 limited edition 12" singles, released weekly in September-December 1988. That never happened, although the labels were printed

Anyway, the "pure trance originals" typically refers to the original releases of "What Time is Love?", "3am Eternal" and "Last Train to Trancentral", which are nothing like the later "stadium techno" versions most people are familiar with. They are much slower, and more like ambient stuff. Quite pleasant, but you can see why they weren't very popular
---------------
**2. Shag Times**

A kind of "Greatest Hits" compilation. Contains mostly JAMs stuff, "Doctorin' The Tardis" and a couple of remixed KLF tracks. Annoyingly, all the KLF tracks and remixes are listed as (incorrect) BPM readings, instead of the titles. The gits.
---------------
**3. Kylie Said to Jason**

This was going to be the first single off the "White Room" soundtrack (see later). Unfortunately, it bombed, and so the soundtrack was never released. Which is a shame really as this track is excellent. Reminds me of "Domino Dancing" by the Pet Shop Boys, but with better singing
---------------
**4. The White Room (OST)**

When "Kylie Said to Jason" tanked, this release was cancelled, despite it already being completed. So the studio engineer stole copies and leaked it out, so it's quite easy to find. The tracks on this differ quite a lot from the "proper" White Room album. Very pleasant light synth-pop stuff, especially "Kylie Said to Jason", the album version of "3am Eternal" (a cut-down version of the "pure trance" mix) and "Go to Sleep"
---------------
**5. The White Room (The film)**

Made using the money they got from TheJAMs and "Doctorin' The Tardis", it's a 50 minute ambient road movie describing Bill and Jimmy's quest to find "The White Room". Unfortunately it's rather dull. Only been shown in public once. Allegedly made because they received letters from someone claiming to be from the Illuminatus. Spot the flaw there. Anyway... they were given a contract which required them to make "an artistic representation of themselves on a journey to a place called THE WHITE ROOM". So they did. Hence the film. Duh.

Most of the footage shot was out of focus or otherwise unuseable, and they ran out of money to finish it. They decided on the ending of the film (based on a "get out clause" they found on the "real" contract. The plan was to show the film silently, and play the soundtrack live. Unfortunately the film is kind of tedious, and the failure of "Kylie Said to Jason" didn't help. The plan was to have an "inner" film and an "outer" film, with the driving-footage being the inner film, and the "outer" film telling the plot. They couldn't find sponsors to finish the film as apparently it was "too weird". The plot itself isn't too well known, but it is believed that it follows the story of the Illuminatus and the Justified Ancients of Mu Mu. 

Seems once they because successes through their "Stadium techno" releases, they kind of lost interest in the film. A shame really. In addition, no-one knows what happened to the original film. All that remains is a mostly-silent 42 minutes film, with the soundtrack dubbed on from the official soundtrack in appropriate places (so there are long periods of silence with not much happening). Still intriguing to watch though
---------------
**6. Chill Out**

Recorded live, without edits, in one take, by the KLF only. Every time they made a mistake, they started over.

'The UK CD has only one track, 45 minutes long. The US CD separates this into 14 tracks, based on the "song" titles and approximate timings printed on the label of the UK LP. It seems that the KLF consider Chill Out to be one continuous piece of music, but had to invent a separation into songs so that song-writing royalties can be paid to those sampled' (KLF FAQ)
---------------
**7. Live at Trancentral/SSL/Lost Continent**

The "Stadium techno" releases of "3am Eternal", "Last Train to Trancentral" and "What Time is Love" most people know the KLF for. Not really live at Trancentral/The SSL/The Lost Continent, they instead used crowd samples. Natch.
---------------
**8. The White Room (Album)**

The only "real" album the KLF released, and it isn't what people were expecting. It still sold millions though. The first half comprises of the "live" versions of their well known tracks (see above), and the second half is much more laid back, with heavily remixed versions from the "White Room" soundtrack (no "Kylie" though), ending with an absolutely *beautiful* version of "Justified and Ancient"

The US version ruined this and edited the first five tracks, eliminating the crowd noise and generally making a mess of it. It jumps and cuts very abruptly. The US edition also has the single mix of 'Last Train To Trancentral' instead of the mellower UK album version, edits 'No More Tears' down from 9:24 to 6:42, and adds a little more wind noise at the end of the closing 'Justified and Ancient'
---------------
**9. America - What Time is Love?**

A remixed and remastered version, since the KLF realised they hadn't "Broken America" yet. Seems to appeal to patriotism, using phrases such as "This great land" and chants of "America" throughout. Quite funny to listen to objectively as it makes you realise quite how manipulative it is. Still sold well though

I'm sure "America - Fuck Yeah!" from TeamAmericaWorldPolice is an indirect parody of this, because the crowd chants are very similar, and they both end with a long list of "great" things, though in this case it's the names of cities
---------------
**10. The Rites of Mu**

This took place during the 1991 Summer Solstice. A small group of journalists and reporters were invited to the "Lost Continent of Mu". "The guests were welcomed from the ferry by Mu passport control officer Drummond in peaked cap and shades, who checked their passports and stamped them with a pyramid blaster stamp. They then allowed themselves to be dressed in yellow ceremonial robes, and led in a chanting procession by a white robed high priest of Mu with Horned God headpiece, over the moors to a bonfire beside a huge wicker man, arms raised with weapons poised, head looking up to the sky. The four angels of Mu, in white dresses, with flower head-bands, rose from the sea, and joined the celebrants. The high priest addressed the crowd in 'a tongue that no longer exists, at least not in this world'. What did the KLF have in store, or was it the Justified Ancients Of Mu Mu controlling the KLF? As the ceremony reached its climax at midnight on the longest day, it was still light. The priest encouraged the guests to direct their psychic energy towards the wicker man, chanting 'Burn Burn Burn' and the idol burst into flames! What lay ahead was 'enlightenment ... or madness'. After the ceremony was over the guests were treated to a huge party. The next day is unrecorded but judging by the statement it involved savouring the undervalued qualities of waiting. However they spent the time, by Sunday 23rd of June, the KLF had transported the guests to the Liverpool Festival of Comedy, where, hooded, they joined them on stage for an accapella rendition of Justified And Ancient as Bill and Jimmy handed out ice creams from an ice-cream van which they had borrowed. The total cost of the weekend was supposed to be around 70,000 ukpounds. But for what?" (KLF FAQ)

Who knows. But the transcription CD makes interesting listening
---------------
**11. Justified and Ancient (Stand by the JAMs)**

Their best known work, partially thanks to a wonderful country singer called TammyWynette (RIP). Quite different from the album version, and includes such things as a rap and a bouncier drum loop. Their last "official" release0
---------------
**12. The KLF with Extreme Noise Terror (BRIT awards)**

"Somehow the KLF persuaded the organisers to let them perform with Extreme Noise Terror, and they began to plan their performance. "The plans kept changing. They varied from me going onstage and literally cutting my age, Manics style into my chest with a knife, to me snogging Jimmy onstage, to Jimmy simulating sex with his girlfriend. Then we were going to cut up a dead sheep on stage and throw blood over the front rows of the audience. The idea was that two thirds of the way through the song this altar would appear with the sheep on... we'd bought the meat cleavers, the knives, the tablecloth, got everything." Drummond explains how such ideas come to them: "we don't always think things through beforehand...we just do them. Jimmy really had me going, he suggested that I use the cleaver to cut my own hand off!"

On the morning of the show (12th February '92) Drummond drove to an abattoir in Northampton and bought a whole dead sheep and eight gallons of blood. Rumours began to circulate of the plan, and first the BBC lawyers and then hardcore vegetarians Extreme Noise Terror made it blatantly known that they were totally against the idea." So the sheep plan was scrapped, and instead *just* the thrash performance, and Bill spraying the audience with blanks from a machine gun took place. There's no doubt however that this performance did annoy, shock and disgust many of the 'pigtails in suits' present in the audience and presumably many of the live TV audience in their living rooms. Trevor Horn (producer of Frankie Goes To Hollywood's "Relax") seemed to be in a state of shock. "They were horrible! Shooting with machine guns! Disgraceful!". Eminent Hungarian classical composer Sir George Solti tried to leave the auditorium during the performance and had to be persuaded to return to his seat.

As Scott Piering's voice announced "The KLF have now left the music business" the two bands hurried off the stage and straight into their van and back to Trancentral. Later in the show The KLF (jointly with Simply Red) were awarded the title Best British Band. Since they had now left the building they sent along sidekick Hector, resplendent in motor cycle messenger gear, to pick up the statuette. Having been told there was no way he was being allowed access, Hector dashed onstage, grabbed the trophy from startled Martika and escaped into the labyrinth of corridors behind the glittering stage. This of course was cut from the TV coverage. Later, he was cornered by security, who wrestled 'the BRIT' back off him.

The BRIT award statuette was later unearthed in a field near Stonehenge by a local farmer. From Q Magazine: "The yeoperson's shovel-wielding presence remains as unexplained as The KLF's wish to bury it there in the first place." Jimmy has been vague when questioned on this." (KLF FAQ)
---------------

Oh, and then there's
---------------
**14. The Black Room**

"The legendary unreleased LP, the darker, harder twin to the White Room LP. It was referred to in interviews for ages, even before the White Room was released. Originally it was planned to be harder techno (like It's Grim Up North), then it was going to be heavy-metal techno (like America - What Time is Love?) and then it was going to be a thrash-metal collaboration with Extreme Noise Terror (like the TOTP version of 3 am Eternal). It's unknown, how much of each incarnation was complete, before it was scrapped and recording was re-started.

Jimmy said of it in December '90: "The 'Black Room' album will all be this kind of electro turbo metal. It's not really industrial like, say, Throbbing Gristle, because it's coming from house and has an uplifting vibe about it. But it's so heavy it will just pin you to the floor."; while Drummond said of it in March '91: "It's the compete yang to the yin of 'The White Room'. It'll be very very dense, very very hardcore. No sort of 'up' choruses or anthems. I think it's going to be techno-metal, I think that's gonna be the sound. Techno-metal. Which'll be, you know, a cross between Techno and Heavy Metal. Megadeth with drum machines."

It never happened. I (PaulMann) have some thrash-metal versions of White Room tracks, but have no way of verifying their source
---------------

This article is about the music, the stunts and the events of BillDrummond and JimmyCauty using the moniker TheTimelords
---------------
**1. "Doctorin' The Tardis"**

A number one single from 1988, comprising part "Blockbuster" by TheSweet, part "Rock and Roll" by GaryGlitter and part DrWho theme

Bill and Jimmy claim the name of the group came shortly after their purchase of an American FordGalaxie police car, which allegedly spoke to them, telling them it's name was "Ford Timelord" (but is probably a reference to DrWho). This car appears both on the cover of the single and in the video for the song itself

Antics include attempting (unsuccessfully) to persuade TheSun to do an interview with the car, claiming it wrote the song (indeed, the car was credited for the single).

B-Side "Gary Joins The TARDIS" is very similar, but with more GaryGlitter vocals

Opinion? It largely sucks, but the "minimal mix" is quite pleasant as there are practically no vocals
---------------
**2. The Manual**

Or "How to have a number one the easy way", a book by BillDrummond which tells you (in step by step instructions) how to have a hit on your hands. This technique was followed by Austrian Eurotrash group Edelweiss, who went on to have a number one record. So there you go

Also released as an Audiobook (but only in German)
---------------
CategoryBands

(The following paragraph is shamelessly stolen from [[Wikipedia]])

//[[TheMoldyPeaches TheMoldyPeaches]] are a self-proclaimed anti-folk group, consisting of, essentially, Adam Green and Kimya Dawson, with the addition of bassist Steve Mertens, drummer Strictly Beats, and guitarists Jack Dishel and Toby Goodshank. Green and Dawson met at Exile on Main Street Records in Mount Kisco, New York, and began working together afterwards. In the early 1990s, the group was part of the New York City underground scene, partially due to the band's strange costumes, reminiscent of The Frogs (Kimmy typically dresses as a rabbit, Adam as Robin Hood - [[KtErrington Kt]]). Touring along with bands such as The Strokes and Tenacious D, The Moldy Peaches have released two albums with Sanctuary Records.//

This article is about the music, the stunts and the events of BillDrummond and JimmyCauty using the moniker TheKFoundation
---------------
**1. The K-F Prize**

The first thing anybody knew about TheKFoundation was when a series of adverts started appearing in national newspapers, declaring such bizarre phrases as "Kick out the clocks" and "K time", followed by "Abandon All Art Now"!

Two weeks later, another advert appeared, announcing "It has come to our attention that you did not abandon all art now. Further direct action is thus necessary. The K Foundation announce the 'mutha of all awards', the 1994 K Foundation award for the worst artist of the year"

And they did. Coincidentally their shortlist was identical to that of the Turner prize, and the same person won. The K-Foundation prize was double that of the Turner prize (40,000)

The festival took place in a field, and the money was delivered in two bright orange armoured cars, with "K Cera Cera" and ABBA's "Money Money Money" blasting over the radio

(See "Nailed to a wall)

They then returned to the arts gallery, and announced that Rachael Whiteread (the Turner prize winner) had won the prize and if she didn't collect it, it would be burnt. She didn't make an apperance until someone caught sight of [[Gimpo]] fiddling with the lighter fluid and matches. The money was donated to needy artists
----------------
**2. Nailed to a wall**

During the K-F Prize, A million pounds in 50 notes was nailed to a large piece of wood and titled "Nailed to a wall". It was then auctioned, with the starting price at half a million, on the grounds that inflation will erode it's value over time, but art is priceless.

Since the money now had holes in it, the Bank of England wouldn't take it back, and fined Bill and Jimmy 9000 for damaging money, and charged them 500 to reprint it.

Sources can't confirm this, but it may have given them ideas for their next stunt...
----------------
**3. 'Watch the K Foundation Burn a Million Quid'**

They did. It was filmed by [[Gimpo]], and took place on the isle of Jura, Scotland. Yes, they really did it. There is video footage, witnesses, the bank confirmed it, and burnt 50 notes kept appearing over the isle for the following few days.

Bill and Jimmy brought back around 80,000 of it (partially burnt) and paid a potter to bake them into a brick. Which he did. And then they filmed it. It's called "The Brick". It's a 3-minute shot of a brick. So there you are. 

The film was taken around festivals and the like for a while, but interest was waning. Both for the audience and for the artists. So Bill and Jimmy signed a contract not to talk about the incident for 23 years. (on the bonnet of a car which they then pushed into the sea)

----------------
**4. K-Cera-Cera**

"Available nowhere ... no formats" and not planned for release until world peace was established. At least, that's what the adverts said. But it did get a very limited release (3000) in Israel following the peace accord.

Bill and Jimmy actually got the Red Army Choir to sing a version of "Que Cera Cera", followed by "War Is Over (If You Want It)" (yes, *that* song). The end result is interesting, and certainly enjoyable
---------------

This article is about the music, the stunts and the events of BillDrummond and JimmyCauty using the moniker TheJams
---------------
Appeared in two guises several years apart:

A. The JAMs - Scottish rap
B. The JAMs - Dark electronic
---------------
**1. "What the Fuck Is Going On?"**

Debut album, pulled from the shelves almost straight away due to gratuitous unlicensed sampling (particularly the entire chorus of ABBAs' 'Dancing Queen' for "The Queen and I"). So they went to Sweden to talk to ABBA. There is no record of them ever actually *meeting* ABBA, so they burnt most of the records in a farmer's field (and received a shotgun blast to the car to show for it) and threw some more in the sea on the ferry during the trip back

The music? Lots of sampling and angry shouty Scottish rapping. Quite funny though

---------------
**2. The JAMs 45 edits**

A sarcastic re-release of "What the Fuck Is Going On?" minus all the samples (with accompanying instructions on how to put them back in yourself)
---------------
**3. "Whitney Joins the JAMs"**

Apparently "Made in Scotland" (according to the record label anyway). Curious sampling of random Whitney records (strangely, there is no record of there being a complaint, so maybe they actually paid this time). Quite catchy. Released as a one-sided records (the other being a test tone)
---------------
**4. "Down Town"**

Samples a song I'm not familar with, but it's good
---------------
**5. "Deep Shit"**

A 500 copy flexi disc accompanied by a comic drawn by Jimmy. Never released because apparently the comic was "crap". Apparently it does turn up in odd places though

Allegedly re-released as "Deep Shit part 2 and 3 of the illegal remix" during the KLF time. Copies have been seen, but nobody seems to have them. Hmm...
---------------
**6. "Burn the Bastards"**

Don't know much about this, other than it was retitled "Burn the Beat" for radio play

The JAMs name was then not used for some time, until they returned with
---------------
**7. "It's Grim Up North"**

A pretty dark electro track. Lyrics consist mostly of reading out names of towns in the north, ending with a sample of "Jerusalem". Supposedly a precursor to the never-released "Black Room" (See TheKLF for more)

The best kind of DanceMusic

Almost always in 4/4 time with a BPM of one of the following: 96/110/120/125/133/135/140/160

Typically carries a back-beat. A repetitive bass-line alternating with the drum beat used to be called HiNrg, but that phrase has fallen out of use since the mid-90s

Earned a bad reputation largely thanks to [[2Unlimited 2 Unlimited]], who bastardised it into something BubblegumPop listeners could cope with ("Techno techno techno techno")

The [[America US]] seem to have a very strange idea of techno, and to them it is what would we would refer to as SynthPop or Electronica

Examples under the US definition: [[Moby]], [[Erasure]], [[PetShopBoys]], The ThompsonTwins, DepecheMode
Examples under the UK definition: [[Royksopp]], ManhattanClique, [[Faithless]], [[Fragma]], ApoptygmaBerzerk and most "hard dance music"

[[Scooter]] falls somewhere in between, which is more like EuroDance 

See also HipHop

CategoryMusicGenres

DanceMusic was developed by German scientists working in secret during the cold war. It is a curious, early example of the MusicalWeapon, a phenomenon which was to finally find its home in late twentieth century PopMusic.

It was designed to gradually destroy the brain and turn any innocent person hearing it into a mindlessly gyrating idiot; its use was an important step in the German plan to gain the ascendancy. However, the early specimens were leaked and so most people became immune to it before it could be perfected.

== AberWorld ==

AberWorld (a.k.a. [[AberystwythTown Aberystwyth]]) is [[http://www.aber.org.uk/toys/dictionary/display.php?entry=AberWorld defined]] by [[http://www.aber.org.uk/toys/dictionary/ the #aber dictionary]] as follows:

//Large theme park built on the mouth of the RiverYstwyth on the west coast of [[Wales]], aimed mainly at the student and tourist markets. Like any other theme park, AberWorld offers an escape from reality to all visitors, some of whom stay many many years in order to avoid accepting real life outside the safetly and confines of the AberWorldUnrealityZone. However, eventually all visitors find that once they've ridden all the local rides at least 50 times and completely exhausted all the public house sideshows, they are left with little choice but to surrender their season ticket and return to a semblance of NormalLife elsewhere. This is normally not unrelated to lack of funds (and indeed ever decreasing number of friends) resulting from AberWorld's dire employment market. Some find employment as AberWorld staff, but are doomed to soul crushing bitterness and poor income and don't last for long, especially when they see former visitors to the park LivingItUp in other areas of the country.//

Not to be confused with GrobbitWorld.

Nor with [[Lesbia]].

===About Branwens===

//"Shitty university canteen which doles out food you thought you'd left behind at SecondarySchool."//

Branwens is a UWA mess-hall. More specifically, it's split into Branwens Upper (which do hot food at lunch time, and aren't open in the evenings), and the original Branwens (which does hot food in the evenings and shitty baguettes at lunchtime). 

Branwen's is open from 8am to 7pm, Monday to Friday, and 10am to 2pm on weekends. Branwens Uppen is open from noon to 2pm on weekdays, and never at weekends. 	 	

One of the few good things about Branwens, is the free WiFi access.

The 'official' Branwens web page is [[http://www.aber.ac.uk/residential/hospitality/branwens.shtml here]].

ChezGeek is a card game by SteveJacksonGames after which GeekNight (a board/card games night at [[DanHuntley Dan]] and [[ClaireMelton Claire]]'s place) is named, which uses a special deck of cards including:

~- Jobs, such as "Corporate Drone", "[[FastFoodCateringAssistant Lord Of The Fries]]", "[[PizzaDeliveryDriver Pizza Delivery Driver]]", and "[[WebDesigner Web Designer]]"
~- Things, some of which are in turn subcategorised into Food, Weed, [[Cigarettes]], Booze, etc. It is possible for a Thing to inhabit two categories (for example, HashBrownies are both Food and Weed).
~- [[SomePeople People]], some of which are good (e.g. "The Shopper", "Mr. Enthusiastic", "Nookie Monster"), and some of which are not (e.g. "Death Of The Party", "The Whiner", "Clumsy Drunk"). Some of these are subcategorised as Cat and Dog cards.
~- Activities, some of which are subcategorised into [[Sex Nookie]], Sleep, TV, etc.
~- "Whenever" cards, which can usually be played at any time, even when it's not your turn. Some of these are designed to help you (e.g. increasing you income, like "Change In Couch"), whereas others are designed to make life difficult for other players (e.g. "Moron With Chainsaw", which prevents the successful playing of a Sleep [Activity] card).

The aim of the game is to earn a particular 'score' of "Slack Points", by eating, sleeping, taking drugs, drinking, getting [[Sex nookie]], etc. Various special rules add flavour to the game, such as the rule that when somebody gets "NoisyNookie" ([[Sex Nookie]] worth 5 or more "Slack Points", those people in the rooms next door to them (adjacant to them at the table) each lose one Sleep card that they already have in play... and that TV cards can be played as Whenever cards in order to cancel any Activity ("No, you're not Going To Concert, you're staying at home and watching Hitler Science Theatre 2000").

Several house rules have come up at GeekNight - these include:

~- Every time you play a card that cancels sleep (for example, "Party Next Door") you must make the appropriate sound effects (e.g. "Whumpa! Whumpa! Whumpa! Whumpa!").
~- A selection of personalised extra cards, including "[[LizHague Liz]]" and "[[KitLane Kit]]" (Person cards) and "Cornetto" (a special Food card, and a reference to this film ShaunOfTheDead, which can be played when //another// player goes shopping).

There are several add-on packs for ChezGeek, including ChezGreek, ChezGrunt, and ChezGoth.

----
See also: [[http://www.sjgames.com/chezgeek/ Official Chez Geek web site]]
[[CategoryCardGames See other card games]]

Munchkin is a custom card game by SteveJacksonGames, somewhat reminiscient of ChezGeek, and played at GeekNight. It is styled on RolePlayingGames, but with strange "munchkinly" rules. In the game, players try to [[Kill kill]] monsters and steal their treasure, and to backstab one another in the process. It requires a good deal of co-operation: particularly early in the game (like [[HackerGame Hacker]], also by SteveJacksonGames), and leads to some hilarious outcomes - //"Do not truffle with the humungous fungus!!"//

TigrisAndEuphrates is an immensely clever tile-laying game by MayfairGames, played on occassion at GeekNight. In it, two to four players attempt to control sectors of the economy in the region between the Tigris and Euphrates river - the cradle of human civilisation - by placing tiles and tokens in order to construct linked territories, and fight with neighbouring territories. Like all great games, the rules are quite simple but there are a great number of different strategies for success.

For a good period of time, TigrisAndEuphrates has ranked at number 2 in the [[http://www.boardgamegeek.com/rankbrowse.php3 Top Games List]] on [[http://www.boardgamegeek.com/ Board Game Geek]]. Read more about it [[http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/42 on their site]].

[[CategoryBoardGames See other board games]]

A board game based on the famous book (the) LordOfTheRings, by JRR Tolkein, and marketed, rather cleverly, on the back of the LordOfTheRingsFilms. Presumably this causes a lot of people who bought it because the liked the CGI in the films to get really confused when you see nonsensical special cards.

The "Special Cards," generally featuring entirely random subcharacters are helpful to the players because they tilt the balance of power every so slightly in favour of the people who own the game. 

This is necessary because the game is a co-operative game, where every player has to help the other. They are persuaded to refrain from [[MunchkinGame Munchkinly]] tactics by the fact the game is weighted severely in favour of the game, which constitutes the opposition entirely by itself.

Whoever wrote the game was a clever, devious bastard. The success rate is about 1-in-3 on the easy setting.

And it's great fun.

{{image src="http://www.sjgames.com/hacker/img/deluxe_hacker_sm.jpg" class="left"}}[[HackerGame Hacker]] is a custom card game by SteveJacksonGames. It features a particularly complicated ruleset, and some horrendous in-game mathematics (have a MathMonkey around whenever you're playing it!), but it's still a great game. In the game, players (hackers) have to try to gain access to as many systems as possible - systems are represented by cards, each with potential connections on their 'edges' to other nearby systems. Co-operation is encouraged to a high degree (//"I'll give you the information you need to hack into ThePentagon if you give me your Hackintosh!"//), but backstabbing is common.

DanHuntley thinks that the game would make a fantastic multiplayer computer game, and keeps promising to have a go at making it. However, as he's always promising such things, he's got far too many projects on the go to finish any given one of them.

The picture to the left is of the front of the box.

2. Possible the result of interbreeding between [[Goblins]] and [[Orcs]]. Hobgoblins are tall gangling creatures encountered in many wild areas. Unlike [[Goblins]], with whom they will sometimes be living, they are not afraid of sunlight, and make fearsome opponents both above and below ground. They are as tall as men, typically dress in tattered clothes and armour stolen from past opponents, and carry swords or spiked clubs. Like their cousins they revel in torture and death, especially where [[Elves]] are concerned. They are ugly, warty-skinned things, and hate anything that is in the slightest way graceful or pretty (hence [[Elves]]).

Hobgoblins may be encountered living in primitive settlements is isolated lands, but most of their number serve in the armies of Chaos alongside their inhuman cousins. They are hardy fighters, and may sometimes be encountered leading small companies of [[Goblins]] or [[Orcs]] into battle. Despite such a rare gift for discipline, they will just as quickly lose it if faced with an [[Elves Elf]] or two, and will attack them rabidly without thought for their commands.

CategoryElectronics

If you want more, see [[AmigaOS]]

Amiga (Spanish for "Girlfriend" - awwww) is a term used to describe a range of products marketed by Commodore (though not originally made by them) in the 80s and 90s

Practically invented the European DemoScene. Never terribly popular in the US

Almost bought by Atari, but Commodore got it instead.

(in very rough chronological order)

====A1000====
68000 at 7.14Mhz
Horrible. 256kb RAM. OperatingSystem came on floppy, which had to be booted before you could run anything, even self-booting applications. Kickstart 1.0

====A500====
68000 at 7.14Mhz
The first useable Amiga. 512k RAM. Kickstart 1.2. Has "Rock Lobster" inscribed on the motherboard because the developers were B52 fans. Immensely popular, and considered the "base unit" for about 6 years. Expansion slot known as the "trapdoor" due to it's location

====A2000 A2500/B2000====
68000 at 7.14Mhz, except for Unix A2000 with 68020 at 14.28Mhz
Business machines. Some came with a variation of Unix. Expansion slots known as "Zorro" slots. 2500 had 1Mb of RAM and Kickstart 1.3, others had 512kb and Kickstart 1.2. Came with built in hard drive

====A3000====
68020 at 14.28Mhz
The first seriously high-end Amiga. The Video Toaster (see later) was produced for this. Came with "Zorro 2" expansion slots. 6Mb of RAM. Wow. Hideously expensive (I believe the model number reflects the price). Also available in Unix flavour. Came with Kickstart 2.04. Also available in tower format. Built in hard drive. Introduction of ECS chipset

====CDTV====
68000 at 7.14Mhz
A mistake. Cost around five hundred pounds. Basically an A500 with no keyboard, mouse or floppy drive, a cheap CD-unit, and an AWFUL handset. Could still play Lemmings and Sim City though. Came with Kickstart 1.3 despite 2.04 already completed

====A1500====
68000 at 7.14Mhz
An A2000 with no hard drive and two floppy drives

====A500+ A600====
68000 at 7.14Mhz
A replacement for the A500 with 1Mb of RAM as standard, Kickstart 2.04 and ECS chipset. A600 produced later (Almost called A300, but they wanted it to sound like an upgrade - motherboard still says A300), and was almost identical except for the lack of a numeric keypad, and a PCMCIA slot instead of a trapdoor

====A4000/040 A4000/060====
68040 at 40Mhz, or 68060 at 60Mhz
The best equipped Amiga ever produced. Came with the brand new Kickstart 3.01. Available in a tower. 2Mb of RAM. "Zorro 3" expansion slots, on a par with PCI (Though horribly incompatible due to the Motorola/Intel byte patterns being opposite). New AGA graphics chipset

====A1200====
68EC020 at 14.28Mhz (no FPU)
A home users version of the A4000. Slower CPU (14.14Mhz), but still came with 2Mb of RAM, which surprised a lot of people. PCMCIA slot.  Workbench 3.0

====CD32====
68EC020 at 14.28Mhz (no FPU)
To the A1200 what the CDTV was to the A500. A better start, and much cheaper. In fact, quite a few titles were ported to the platform. Could play VideoCds, IF you bought the FMV module (60 or so), due to the native CPU not being fast enough. Not compatible with most CDTV titles

====Custom Chips====
What made the Amiga the most powerful home computer were it's custom chip sets. Individual chips to handle different tasks, taking the burden away from the CPU. Be fair, at the time, the Amiga was way ahead of the PC, just thanks to Commodore it was still in the same place 5 years later

Agnus / Alice - the graphics chip. OCS (Original Chipset) and ECS (Enhanced Chipset) allowed up to 64 colours at 640x400. AGA (Advanced Graphics Architecture, and the source of endless puns) allowed up to 256 colours at 640x400, and had a built in blitter

Paula - the sound chip. Could mix up to four channels of incoming data (including resampling if needed) and output as a stereo steam.  The tracker module originated on the Amiga due to the power of this chip

There are more, but they aren't interesting. The CIA chips controlled the keyboard and disk drive, for example

====Titles====
Lemmings, Worms, Zool, 3D Construction Kit, AMOS (Later STOS for the Atari and KlikAndPlay for the PC), Alien Breed, Cadaver, Gods, Magic Pockets, Speedball, James Pond (and Robocod), Pinball Fantasies, Theme Park, Cybercon 3, Chips Challenge (Later part of the Microsoft Entertainment Pack), Llamatron, Lotus I II and III, Prince of Persia, Beneath a Steel Sky, The Secret Of Monkey Island, Captive, Loom, Syndicate, The Chaos Engine, Chuck Rock, Shadow of the Beast, Xenon 2, Sim City and most popular AtariSt titles originated on the Amiga, and promptly suffered in the transition (1/4 the number of colours and chip sound). Or worse, they were ported to the PC (In early cases, down to 4-16 colours, one channel sound)

In addition, serious titles like Deluxe Paint, POV-Ray, Lightwave (which led to the creation of 3D Studio Max as a competitor) and Cubase (almost certainly the origins of PropellorheadReason) had their origins on the Amiga

====Advancements and Plugins====
A501 and A520 were a hard drive and a memory expansion (not in that order) for the A500. Official CD drive produced for the A1200, but were beaten to the punch by Zappo, who produced one 6 months earlier for about 100 less. Squirrel card allowed SCSI devices to be connected to the A1200, A600 and A4000. A few network cards produced, but most Amiga users connected via modem using AmiTCP

The likes of Power Computing produced lots of cool hardware for the Amiga, such as accelerator cards which could speed up your A1200 to up to 60Mhz with 20Mb of RAM. Nice. Or the Video Toaster which was used to produce a lot of video effects, including all the CGI for BabylonFive, and the videoscreen at the MiamiDolphins stadium in Florida. But people didn't want to upgrade

Graphics cards became quite popular, with the likes of Picasso and Retina allowing 16-million colour in 800x600. A seriously nice piece of kit with practically no performance hit

====What Happened Next====
Commodore made hundreds of stupid decisions and it just became out-dated. The Amiga is still technically around ("AmigaOne"), but now it runs a form of BSD and uses Mac hardware, so you wonder how they can get away with calling it an Amiga

Emulation is still very popular, and we have only just managed to get PCs which can successfully emulate the Amiga's custom chipset at any speed.

Games are still being produced, an example being "Payback", at GTA clone. Not bad for 14.28Mhz, eh?

====Pointless Trivia====
The Amiga floppy drive had a seek time of 4ms, slightly slower than the Atari's 3ms, but given they had at least twice as much memory, they didn't spend as long accessing the disk :)

One of the first computers to have a built in GUI as standard

HAM-mode allowed up to (around) 262,400 colours to be displayed at once (still image only). This was done with some seriously messed-up maths which aren't important to this Wiki. Plus, the sheer size of the files meant most of your memory was gone while you displayed the picture

The Amiga had two types of memory. Chip memory and Fast memory. Both were identical physically, but the physical memory was divided up upon boot-up. Chip memory could be accessed by any of the chips, and fast memory could only be accessed by the CPU. Simple. However, any memory added via expansion boards could only be fast memory. There was no way to increase the amount of chip memory. 2Mb was your lot. In addition, some early programs and demos _required_ fast memory. Luckily there were software programs to dynamically shift the boundary, providing you had the free RAM to do it

The 68000 range of CPUs only used the even numbers. 68010 was an aborted attempt at acceleration, and only 000,020,040 and 060 were used. Rumours about of an 030, but I've never seen one. I think there may have been an accelerator for the A1200 with one...

An alternative/progressive rock band (or maybe not, depending on whether you mind definitions) formed around the songwriting abilities of one of the founding members, [[E]].

The band formed in 1996 or 1998 with Tommy playing Bass guitars, Butch on percussion and [[E]] on lead guitar, glockenspiel (which then becomes the rockenspiel) and wurlitzer. They all provided vocals and [[E]] was heavily involved in production of each of their records.

The band has gone through some personnel changes however [[E]] has remained constant and, much to the disamy of many [[eels]] fans, Butch has recently announced his departure from the group citing business, and not personal or creative, differences.

[[eels]] (no 'The') sidled onto the music scene in 1998 with their debut album BeautifulFreak. They did not burst, nor explode but slowly drew cult recognition in the US and more widespread following in Europe. BeautifulFreak was hailed for its haunting and touching lyric and excellent production and provided two of [[eels]] chart hits; //Beautiful Freak// and //Novocaine For The Soul//.

Fans were forced to wait two years for the next album due to the deaths of many of [[E]]'s family and friends. His mother suffered from, and eventually succumbed to cancer and his sister Elizabeth took her own life. The first track of the album ElectroshockBlues was titled //Elizabeth On The Bathroom Floor// and spoke directly of her suicide. The track //The Medication Is Wearing Off// was written as a response to //Novocaine For The Soul// to describe the loss of cynical detachment and the gain of pain. The album was described by [[E]] as the most up-beat he would ever produce because, whilst it dealt with the death of his family it also focused on his passage through the grief and the reasons to carry on living. Whilst the melodies and the majority of the lyrics of the ElectroshockBlues album are depressing the song will almost always end with an acceptance of life over death.

Having worked through many of his emotional problems [[E]] was able to make DaisiesOfTheGalaxy a pleasent and joyful album (comparatively) and much more of a crowd pleaser.

[[Souljacker]] was conceived, mainly, whilst [[E]] was ona spiritual retreat at which he was not allowed to speak or write. He became so creative during this time that he felt compelled to write what would become //Souljacker Part 2// on toilet roll and to hide it from the other members of the retreat. The album was co-produced by JohnParish and was another critical smash for [[eels]]. My particular favourite on the album is the track //Fresh Feeling//, a love song that re-uses a string quartet phrase that they used earlier in their career on the track //Selective Memory//. [[eels]] had used a similar trick before turning the instrumental for an early B-Side track Dog's Life into the instrumental for their song EfilsGod. What [[eels]] had started other bands had used and reaped rewards for.

The following album [[Shootenanny]]! (a term coined by [[E]] to describe a [[Hootennany]] with guns) was far less autobiographical and featured a number of songs that could be considered as coming very close to jokes (//Fashion Awards// and //Restraining Order Blues//) and whilst there were a couple od songs that spoke of depression they were non-specific. This turn angered many of the 'hardcore' fans who favoured the more emotional tracks that had been produced in the past. But no-one disputed that they still rocked.

A new album is due for release in 2005 and it is unsure whether Butch will be providing the percussion accompaniment but what you can be sure of (apart from cliches in summaries) is that it will be bought by their fans and that those determined few will try to enlighten the rest of the world to their greatness.


Best Album: [[Souljacker]]

HarukiMurakami is a Japanese author of the post-war baby-boom generation. 

His style is, I suppose, mundane poetry. Most of his works shares the common themes of vice, death, growing up and beauty in unexpected places. 

**List of works (or at least the ones JonAtkinson owns) with short descriptions:**

~-TheWindupBirdChronicle - I very twisty novel that starts with Noboru Wataya (a cat) going missing, and ends with the Japanese massacres in Manchuria in WorldWarII. I think it's overrated.

~-TheElephantVanishes - A collection of short stories. Most don't cover much time, so they're a little like looking at paintings, or polaroid photos. Interesting, because some of his characters from other books started from these short stories.

~-AWildSheepChase - An unnamed protaganist starts to recieve strange letters from his friend, TheRat, and is contacted by a shadowy media organisation to track down a particular sheep from a particular photograph. Along the way, he stays at the DolphinHotel, meets TheSheepMan, and loses his girlfriend.

~-DanceDanceDance - The sequel to AWildSheepChase sees the anonymous anti-hero recovering from the events of the previous book. He decided to put the past to rest, and try to find his lost girlfirend  by returning to the DolphinHotel. However, much has changed, and along the way he meets a depressed movie star, a beautiful 13 year old girl, and a man with one arm. This book also has the only 'cameo' role the author has ever written, appearing as himself under than name HakamiMakiumura.

~-SputnikSweetheart - I wasn't too sure about this one. It has all the right ingredients (inreachable girl, unremarkable protagonist, greek island), but something didn't quite sit correctly with me. The story of Mui was very enjoyable, but I felt the ending brought in a new relationship too late in the novel. One for the hardcore, but the conclusion leaves you a little empty.

~-AfterTheQuake - A collection of short stories all connected with the Kobe earthquake.

~-NorwegianWood - A story about a student who falls in love while at university. When his lover vanishes, he sets off to find her in an asylum, and learns of her roomates past.

~-BirthdayStories - Yes, yes, yes so good. I read this entirely in a couple of hours, and I'm still reeling a few weeks later. It's an anthology, which has short stories revolving around the theme of birthdays, ageing and the passage of time from (among others) PaulTheroux, DenisJohnson, RaymondCarver and RusselBanks. Murakami adds his own story too. I think the best story was probably 'The Birthday Cake', by DanielLyons.

~-Hard-boilder Wonderland and the End of the World - Got this from [[HayleyDrew]] for Valentines day. Not read it yet.

~-South of the Border, West of the Sun - As above.

There are more books, but I'll add them as I read them.

**His other works (that SianThomas has read)**

~-Underground - Non-fiction work about the sarin gas attack on the Tokyo underground by members of the Aum cult in which twelve people died and thousands were injured. This book contains interviews with the survivors. Fascinating look at the impact of the event on ordinary people and scary how many people just carried on working while suffering from sarin exposure.

~-KafkaOnTheShore - His latest novel to be published here. Oedipal prophecies, talking cats, Hegel-quoting prostitues, ColonelSanders as a pimp, JohnnieWalker as a kitty killer, fish rainstorms. A bit hard to describe in other words (as with most Murakami) but it's fab.

**Other Resources:**

~- Salon.com has an [[http://www.salon.com/books/int/1997/12/cov_si_16int.html interview]] with Murakami.
~- [[http://www.murakami.ch/main_2.html Murakami.ch]] also has some good articles. I recommend [[http://www.murakami.ch/about_hm/articles/articles_confessions_junkie_sonam_the_hindu.html Confessions Of A Murakami Junkie]]; it describes almost exactly how I feel about Murakami.
~-[[http://www.exorcising-ghosts.co.uk Exorcising Ghosts]] has lots of links to short stories, reviews, interviews etc.

==== StephenHawking ====

=== The Man ===

StephenHawking is one of the world's leading TheoreticalPhysicists. But you already knew that, because you [[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Hawking read about him on Wikipedia]].

=== The Method ===

StephenHawking is the universal constant by which [[ClaireMelton Claire]] argues that it is possible to determine the difference between a game and a sport: that great mystery. This can be determined, [[ClaireMelton Claire]] claims, by working out whether or not StephenHawking can participate in it or not.

If he can participate, it is a game; if he cannot, it is a sport. In order to attempt to prove her wrong, RockMonkey hosts two lists:

== GamesStephenHawkingCantPlay ==
== SportsStephenHawkingCanPlay ==

In that case why are the OlympicGames so called? (Decides this is final evidence that [[ClaireMelton Claire]] is wrong.) - AndyKeohane

He is also perfectly capable of playing TheGame

Please feel free to add to these lists.

=== Using The ChatRoom ===
This is the RockMonkey ChatRoom. If you're going to be hanging around on RockMonkey for hours on end, why not open this RockMonkey WikiPage in a seperate WebBrowser tab (or window, if you're using an inferior WebBrowser), and keep in touch with other RockMonkey users.

Yes; it's [[InternetRelayChat IRC]], which means that the usual commands work:

~- Use "/nick newname to change your name. 
~- Use "/msg otherperson secret message" to send a message to another person.
~- Use "/quit Gotta go wash my socks" to quit, sending a logoff message to the room
~- If you want to connect with a 'traditional' [[InternetRelayChat IRC]] client, point it at a Freenode server (e.g. orwell.freenode.net), channel """#RockMonkey"""
----
=== [[Igneous]] ===
[[Igneous]] (or "Iggy", as he's known to his friends) is a robot who hangs around in the ChatRoom. He's talkative, but a little stupid. Help him learn things by telling him about them (and ask him about them later!). He also helps collect the ChatRoomStats.

A condition in which a [[Catholic]] receives one or more of the wounds that were inflicted upon JesusChrist in the run up to [[Passover]].

[[JesusChrist Jesus]] (I'm going to avoid JesusChrist as it attaches religious connotations to the historical character and it'll avoid the debate) was [[MisterJTA whipped]]. The device used would likely have included bones plaited into the cord (anyone else a little bit disconcerted by the combination of flagelation and plaiting?) so that it would have torn chunks from the flesh.

After that thorns were twisted into a crown and forced upon his head.

Thirdly, when he was [[Crucified crucified]] he was nailed to the cross through the wrists and then he was either nailed with one nail through the feet or required to rest his feet upon a blade. The way that the body hangs from the cross constricts the lungs and makes breathing very difficult and so (because they're [[Bastards bastards]]) they would allow you to push yourself up, and breath and prolong your life/suffering,  but destroy your feet and cause you more pain.

Finally, and this is where it can go PearShaped, a spear was punged through his side. The thing is this is given as a proof that Jesus did in fact die because when the spear pierced his side  blood and water flowed out. If this is true then Jesus did not suffer the spear through his side and so how can it be considered part of the [[Stigmata stigmata]]?

====Trout====

Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) are considered a cold water fish, meaning they require low water temperatures and high levels of dissolved oxygen in order to survive.  The optimal temperature for an ideal trout habitat is between 50 and 65 F.  They begin to show signs of stress at temperatures exceeding 70 F, and will most likely die in 80 F water. Trout can tolerate pH as low as 4.1 and as high as 9.5.  In terms of general habitat, Trout live in many different situations.  Lakes ranging in size as found at Tenterden Trout Waters are ideal.

No one has ever seen a [[Trout]] take heroin.

Discuss [[Trout]] in relation to [[Herring]] [[TroutVsHerring here]]

====Herring====

The Atlantic herring (Clupea harengus) is one of nearly 200 herring species in the family Clupeidae. One of the most important and abundant fish in Gulf of Maine, the Atlantic herring has provided food and lobster bait for coastal communities and forms a critical link between plankton and the animals that prey on herring.

Rocks and the [[Minerals]] that make them up are the tangible record of geological processes.. The minerals of the Earth are understood in terms of their molecular architecture (the way their atoms are arranged in crystal structures). The kinds of atoms and their chemical bonding determine not only the crystal structures but the chemical and physical properties of the mineral, all of which are used for identification. Rocks are divided into three major groups [[IgneousRocks igneous]], [[MetamorphicRocks metamorphic]] and [[SedimentaryRocks sedimentary]], on the basis of origin. They are further subdivided within each group according to mineral composition and texture, which provide the data to allow interpretation of their origin.

If [[FreeWill free will]] is a 'figment of our imagination' then it is no more or less so than anything else we perceive. 'Figment of the imagination' is derogatory and implies some kind of misguidedness, invalidity or even childishness. I would prefer "construct of the human '[[TheMind mind]]'" - a definition which can be applied to anything you see, touch, smell, taste, hear, remember, think, etc etc... Since nothing exists outside our [[TheMind minds]] we have as much free will as we need, which is as much free will as we can subjectively experience. Even if you believe the theories which state that free will does not truly exist to be correct (which I do) then you cannot ever truly experience this to be the case as you perceive choices to be available to you and make them accordingly. The point at which a prediction could realistically be made, at a human level, would only be after the fact of you having made the choice, which isn't really a prediction. The prediction could only be made by what you might call '[[GodKnows God]]' - but that's effectively a different debate. The prediction would be made by something which underlay the universe on some level whether that was metaphysical, spiritual, psychological, neuropsychological or smaller. We are not beings which exist at such a level, we cannot perceive beyond our minds and our minds tell us we have free will. The level at which [[FreeWill free will]] can be proven emphatically to not exist is imperceptible and hypothetical - not to mention impractical. It is correct, but correct at a point of irrelevance. At least if you want to deal with people on the level of Being People. Rather than on some hypothetical philosophical plain underpinned by some transcendental grand narrative, which is other than God but no more realistic.  - RestlessBoy. 

What I was trying to say but better. - AndyKeohane
----
And, in fact, RestlessBoy - as I've always said: it //all// comes down to perception, in the end.

MisterJTA is a member of the LiberalDemocrats and will be voting for them because they appear to be a party willing to do things for other people, and not themselves. Which, frankly, is a fucking miracle these days.

KtErrington will also be voting Liberal Democrat because Labour can't viably be called left-wing any more. The Liberal Democrats would, if elected, increase taxation for the highest earners in Britain, actually ensure Britain meets it's targets under the Kyoto Protocol, start making friends with the UN and (I quote) "forge a new relationship with the United States which is a partnership of influence, and not so subordinate as to appear subservient". 
Another Labour term and we'll be up to our eyeballs with 'the right to chose your children's privately funded school', none of which will be up to standard, some of which will probably specialise in nailcare and nothing else (and be given a grants for reaching their national targets in nailcare) and all of which will reflect the selling out of public services which should be an automatic right for everyone. This is less of an issue than it is in America due to the tighter cohesion within the political parties in the UK as compared to the US (e.g. during GeorgeWBush's presidential election campaign he said that he had not read the Republican Party Platform {basically a manifesto}: can you imagine any politician in the UK saying that?). But then his home seat of BirminghamEdgbaston, was a safe Conservative seat until 1997 and is reasonably safe Labour seat, the LiberalDemocrats always come a very poor third.  He refuses to vote for Vanitas/Veritas, who are also standing in Ceredigion, he dislikes the Conservatives on the large majority of policy issues and Labour do not stand a chance in Ceredigion and MattPayne distrusts them and their policies.  He has no qualms about the PlaidCymru candidate Simon Thomas who has done a decent job and thinks PlaidCymru do actually stick up for Wales whereas the other parties get swamped by London.  He may toss a coin to decide but any reasonable debate anywhere will be helpful.

Update: The LiberalDemocrats won the constituency of Ceredigion taking it away from PlaidCymru with only a 219 vote majority.  Therefore if all those on this page voted LiberalDemocrat and voted in Ceredigion that would make up nearly 5% of their majority.

==== [[PromoSexual Promosexuality]] ====

The term "PromoSexual", typically used in a derogatory sense, is a play-on-words of the word "HomoSexual". A PromoSexual is one who pretends to be of a different sexuality to that which they are, typically to appear 'cool' or to attract members of thier preferred sex. Stereotypical examples include men pretending to be [[Gay gay]] in order to get lots of close female friends, before making thier move, and people in general pretending to be BiSexual in order to ride the now-diminishing wave of popular culture that declared it fashionable to "swing both ways".

He was not dismissed but rather became the guru of those ChineseGuysInTheStreetMakingYourNameOutOfWire, who travel from the FarEast to study under him before going out into the world. 

SwearWords and PaperClips are [[Daventry Daventry's]] two primary exports. The word QuimNinja was the most recent swearword to be created in [[Daventry]], it was not as succesful as previous efforts such as KnobJockey, TwatGoblin and FuckBadger.

It is also home to the famous DaventryMooCowOrchestra.

It was the fourth in a series of 26 planned towns built by the late Dave Entry. The first two [[Aventry]] and [[Baventry]], blew away in a high wind one spring morning. The third, [[Coventry]] is still standing and was awarded non-fictitious status by Sir MargaretThatcher in 1985. The series only got as far as [[Eventry]], but no one has ever been there as Dave won't tell anyone where it is.

It is twinned with the [[French]] town of [[Deriere]].

Famous people born in Daventry include MartinBashir and KermitTheFrog.

CategoryFictionalPlaces

Analogue vs Digital. The final say.

====Why analogue is better====
It has a technically infinite dynamic range, meaning all the subtle nuances of the original performance aren't lost like they are on digital, which has to "cap" the range at some point (It could be very high, but it's still defined). This is why it sounds "warmer"

It's closer to real life, being an imitation rather than an interpretation -- and in two hundred years we'll have much better chance of being able to play back our analogue records than our CDs and DAT tapes. This is because there are many many different ways of storing things digitally (though thankfully we tend to stick to uncompressed PulseCodeModulation, so all we need is the specification and machinery to read it)

====Why digital is better (assuming PCM)====
Due to only having two signal levels, noise has practically no effect on a digital signal, meaning it can be both stored and transmitted with very little in the way of distortion (noise, attenuation etc...)

Specifications allow for error correction, so if bits of information are missing, you can tell, and request it to be sent again. Unless you can't get it again, then you're screwed. Incidentally, Mode 2 CDs (eg audio CDs) have really lousy error correction. It is possible to screw up the transmission and still have a playable source

Digital signals can be compressed (even losslessly) thereby saving space, both in bandwidth and storage requirements. Unfortunately we seem to be favouring lossy compression (like [[MP3]]) and run the risk of losing the original source

So there you go.

This film seems to force people into one of two camps

1. Those who believe the film perfectly describes the feeling of [[ennui]]

2. Those who believe the film causes [[ennui]]

We don't like the second kind of people.

Exhibit B. Roman hedonists (See HedonistBot) would often attempt to make themselves deliberately bored. This requires more concentration and effort (not to mention time) than most people are prepared to give, so it hasn't been practiced much since

Exhibit C. TheGame. Surely something as simple, yet engrossing can only come from [[ennui]]. Anything which relieves boredom yet requires effort defeats its own purpose.

In modern society, it is difficult to achieve a state of [[ennui]], but it is greatly rewarding for small periods at a time (except for the people who call you lazy)

TheStattoJTAPublishingCorporation was founded in 1998 by MisterJTA and his friend [[Statto]] when they were both at AdamsGrammarSchool, who at the time were on a school trip to [[Arthog]], [[Wales]].

The first ever publication was ''The Statto and John Concise English Dictionary'', whose name was soon shortened to ''The Statto Dictionary'', which sought to describe small parts of the English language in an overly complex and cynical fashion. It was inspired by a certain Dr Ehlers, who, unable to think of any other achievements during the week at Arthog, awarded him the prize for "only person to call a spade a primitive human-operated soil moving device." This was soon complicated further, resulting in "primitive humanoid-operated soil particulate realignment device," and became the first definition in the first publication of the Corporation's history.

Having been brought together by the circumstances of unfair groups, the pair set about writing ridiculous numbers of ''Dictionary'' entries, as well as starting a number of so-called 'peripheral publications,' such as ''JTA's Little Red Book'', a collection of witty quotations, and ''Surviving Bus Journeys For Fun!'' a guide to use of public transport.

It was not until the founders were in Year 11, some three years after the creation of The Corporation, that their publishing became accessible to a wider audience. Having previously relied upon the Adams' Library printers, they branched out onto the [[Internet]]. Their first 'Net-specific publication, ''The Curse of the Big Nasty Rabbit'', was a point-and-click [[RPG rle-playing adventure]].

Now, The Corporation has a vast behemoth of a website, over one thousand pages in size, with comprehensive archives of past publications. Their adventures continue...

Operating System used by the [[Amiga]] range of home computers

====Kickstart and Workbench versions====

Kickstart - The kernel. In ROM, except for the A1000
Workbench - The user interface, invoked with the command "loadwb", although a good chunk of it loads anyway to give you the CLI. On disk.

Any workbench version can be used as long as it's major release (number before the decimal point) matches that of the Kickstart

Noteable releases:

~- Kickstart 1.2 - Brilliant white opening screen showing a hand holding a disk. Catchy. Little hard drive support, but it was there. Workbench was a deliberate high-constrast thing of blue and orange. Quite painful to use, and no support to create a new directory. You had to duplicate an existing one. Also, deleted items *had* to be dragged to a trashcan. If there wasn't a trashcan on your disk, you couldn't delete. No commands in memory, not even CD. Two floppy drives or a hard drive essential if you wanted to do anything remotely serious

~- Kickstart 1.3 - Almost identical, but it supported bootable hard drives.

~- Kickstart 2.04 - Low contrast pleasant black/white/grey appearance. Boot screen changed to a purple animation of a disk being inserted into a drive. Introduced delete and new folder commands. Made a lot of commands resident, such as cd, so no need to keep reinserting the Workbench disk. Strangely, commands such as DIR were still disk-based. What most non-Amiga users will be familiar with, due to the popularity of the A500+ and the A600

~- Kickstart 3.01 - Very similar in appearance to 2.04, but the changes under the bonnet were quite significant. Firstly was the support for cd drives, even bootable ones with 3.01 (as opposed to 3.0). Support for graphics cards like the Picasso (see later). Secondly was the introduction of "datatypes". This is essentially identical to the "class-type" idea on PCs, whereby a file _type_ could be assosciated with a program. Small moves... Moved a lot of boot-files to the ROM to increase speed

====Guru Meditation====
If a software failure caused the Amiga to reboot, a flashing red box appeared with the phrase "Guru Meditation". This is supposed to be relaxing. The following codes described the error code and location in memory where it happened. Not much consolation to know that error 0x00000003 means divide by zero when you've just lost 12 hours work. Replaced by "Software Failure" with Workbench 2.04

====Methodology====
Devices and APIs were handled in a very dynamic way by the Amiga. Upon bootup, a variety of directories would be checked:

The C directory, contained commands which could be called from the command line. The default path would point here

The DEVS directory contained drivers for devices (not hard or floppy drives) which might be connected. They had catchy names such as cd.device or scsi.device

The L directory contained disk-validator, a file used to check integrity of the disk. Luckily this silly idea was abolished with Kickstart 2.04

The LIBS directory contained the API for the OS. Some were fairly sensible, such as ARP.library (later ASL.library) (the GUI), and powerpacker.library (for on the fly decompression), to the bizarre mathieeeedoubbas.library and mathieeeedoubbtrans.library (maths functions, I presume)

The S directory contained the catchily-named startup.sequence which was a script called upon bootup

The T directory was always a mystery to me since I never found anything in it

The Amiga never used extensions to identify filetypes. Instead, it relied on the application checking the first few bytes of the file before using it. Hey, it worked. Once datatypes were introduced, the OS could identify and assosciate files on the same principle

This does mean that executable files had to be tagged as such (with the X flag) otherwise the OS would not know they weren't data files

Another flag was the S tag, which meant the file contained a list of commands (like a batch file) to run. If you didn't set the flag, you could still treat a file as such with the EXECUTE command

Native support for PC disks (double density only)

The Amiga uses the same CR/LF format as Unix, so there is no problem reading ASCII files. A tool called Crossdos could be invoked to run in the background (like a daemon or TSR), which would silently convert the end of line characters for you. Wasn't that nice? It also uses Unix backslashes, and many of the commands have similar attributes and names. Ports of RexX and eMacs were available (aRexX and [[EmacsEditor MicroEmacs]] respectively)

==== Zork ====

[[Zork]] is a great InteractiveFiction (a.k.a. text-based adventure) game made by Marc Blank and David Lebling and distributed in the late seventies by [[Infocom]], who were - at the time - the world's biggest distributer of InteractiveFiction games. It comes in three parts ([[Zork]] I, [[Zork]] II, and [[Zork]] III), and features several awful puzzles (such as the "diamond floor" room, the carousel, and the loud room), and several mazes in the confusing style that was traditional for adventure games of it's age. It invented the [[Grue]], which would eat the adventurer if they spent too long wandering around in the dark, and this character was later parodied in many other adventure games, including by the modern [[Zork]] games. It's not possible to call yourself a serious InteractiveFiction player without ever having played [[Zork]].

It's now free to download: [[http://www.csd.uwo.ca/Infocom/download.html get it here]].
----
Following the success of the original [[Zork]] trilogy, the series was extended (in both directions) in later years, with games like ZorkNemesis, BeyondZork, [[ZorkGrandInquisitor Zork: Grand Inquisitor]], ZorkQuest and [[ZorkQuest2 ZorkQuest II], ZorkZero, [[Sorcerer]], the [[Enchanter]] series, [[Spellbreaker]], SpiritWrak, [[ZorkTheUndiscoveredUnderground Zork: The Undiscovered Underground]], ReturnToZork, [[Wishbringer]], and [[Balances]]. Not to mention the stuff contained in the NewZorkTimes. The entire genre has been parodied by games such as [[Dork]].
----
Part of CategoryHomeComputerGames

==== InteractiveFiction ====

InteractiveFiction games, or "text-based adventures", are graphically-simplistic, typically turn-based stories in which the player performs the actions of the main character, or characters, by typing commands at thier keyboard. Early InteractiveFiction, such as the respected "original" [[Adventure]], could only handle simple commands, such as "GO NORTH", or "PICK UP AXE"; but thanks to improved string parsing, greater memory limits, and better ArtificialIntelligence algorithms, have led to dramatic improvements. Even [[Zork]], which was (originally) written in the late seventies, could (by it's later incarnations) accept commands of the form of "OPEN THE CHEST, TAKE EVERYTHING OUT OF IT, THEN GIVE THE AXE TO THE DWARF AND TELL HIM TO CLOSE THE DOOR". Of course, it's not possible to cover every possibility, but for many players, part of the fun of a new adventure game is learning how to best interface with it. Some games even make a game of this, using clever language and puns to disguise the true nature of a particular puzzle in a game.

InteractiveFiction games require a reasonable level of imagination on the part of the player - as there are rarely graphics to convey a sense of what is going on, only text-based descriptions of the rooms and situations function as thier eyes and ears. Purists will sometimes claim that this provides some significant storytelling advantages over modern, graphical adventure games, citing examples such as "A shiver runs down the back of your neck" as notions which are hard or impossible to convey in a graphical environment.

Despite what you might expect, there is still a significant online following in InteractiveFiction games, including annual competitions for InteractiveFiction writers. (if I can be bothered, I'll add some links here - [[DanHuntley Dan]])

If you're interested in giving InteractiveFiction a go, why not start with the stunning [[Photopia]], which is comparatively easy (playing time 30 minutes or so, even for a beginner), very well-written (it's make a great short story) and can be played entirely without having to make notes (unlike many larger adventures). You can [[http://www.scatmania.org/archives/2005/02/26/photopia/ download a copy from scatmania.org]] (preferred - a nice installer for Windows users) or from [[http://adamcadre.ac/photopia.html this page]].
